revision.text:
The following are the events in professional [[sumo]] during [[1992]].
==Tournaments== *Hatsu [[honbasho|basho]], [[Ryōgoku Kokugikan]], [[Tokyo]], 12 – 26 January *Haru basho, [[Osaka Prefectural Gymnasium]], [[Osaka]], 8 – 22 March *Natsu basho, Ryōgoku Kokugikan, Tokyo, 10 – 24 May *Nagoya basho, [[Aichi Prefectural Gymnasium]], [[Nagoya]], 5 – 19 July *Aki basho, Ryōgoku Kokugikan, Tokyo, 13 – 27 September *Kyushu basho, [[Fukuoka International Centre]], [[Kyushu]], 8 – 22 November
==News==
===January=== *''[[Yokozuna]]'' [[Asahifuji]] retires after losing his first three bouts, leaving the injured [[Hokutoumi]] as the only yokozuna on the ''[[banzuke]].'' *[[Maegashira]] [[Takahanada]] wins his first ''[[makuuchi]]'' ''[[yusho]]'' with a 14-1 record, the youngest ever to do so. He wins all three [[Sanshō (sumo)|special prizes]] for Technique, Outstanding Performance and Fighting Spirit. Runner-up is [[Akebono Taro|Akebono]] on 13-2, who shares the Outstanding Performance and Fighting Spirit prizes. ''[[Ōzeki|Ozeki]]'' [[Konishiki]], who won the previous tournament in November 1991 and is aiming for ''yokozuna'' promotion, can only manage third place with a 12-3 score. Takahanada's brother [[Wakahanada]] shares the Technique prize. [[Toyonoumi]] wins the ''[[juryo]]'' division championship. Veteran former ''[[komusubi]]'' [[Tamaryu]] retires.
===February=== *Dewanoumi Oyakata, former ''yokozuna'' [[Sadanoyama]], becomes the chairman of the [[Japan Sumo Association]] after Futagoyama Oyakata, the former ''yokozuna'' [[Wakanohana Kanji I|Wakanohana]], steps down. *Former ''yokozuna'' [[Chiyonofuji]], who retired in May 1991, has his [[danpatsu-shiki|official retirement ceremony]] at the [[Ryogoku Kokugikan]]. *Konishiki and his new wife, a fashion model, hold a wedding reception in Tokyo.
===March=== *Konishiki wins his third career championship with a 13-2 record, but is not promoted to ''yokozuna''. The chairman of the [[Yokozuna Deliberation Council]], Hideo Ueda says, "We want to make doubly sure that Konishiki is worthy to be a grand champion. Therefore, we decided to wait for another tournament."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.si.com/vault/1992/05/18/126516/meat-bomb-konishiki-the-quarter-ton-sumo-wrestler-from-hawaii-has-set-off-an-explosion-of-new-interest----and-controversy----in-the-hidebound-national-sport-of-japan|title=Meat Bomb: Konishiki, the quarter-ton sumo wrestler from Hawaii, has set off an explosion of new interest—and controversy—in the hidebound national sport of Japan|date=18 May 1992|publisher=Sports Illustrated|accessdate=3 August 2018}}</ref>
===April=== *Chiyonofuji becomes head coach of [[Kokonoe stable]]. *Konishiki is quoted in the ''[[New York Times]]'' as saying, "if I were Japanese, I would be there (yokozuna) already," causing an international furore.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/04/22/world/sumo-star-charges-racism-in-japan.html|title=Sumo Star Charges Racism in Japan|date=22 April 1992|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=2 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-04-28/sports/sp-1042_1_japanese-sumo-wrestling|title=Weight on Tradition : At 576 Pounds, Hawaiian Sumo Star Konishiki Has the Japanese Wrestling With Accepting a Foreigner at the Sport's Highest Rank|date=28 April 1992|publisher=LA Times|accessdate=2 August 2018}}</ref>
===May=== *Hokutoumi announces his retirement, leaving no ''yokozuna'' for the first time in over 60 years. *Akebono wins the championship with a 13-2 record and is promoted to ''ozeki''. He also receives the Outstanding Performance award. Konishiki can manage only a 9-6 record, meaning he is no longer on a ''yokozuna'' promotion run and must start over. The runner-up is Wakahanada on 11-4, who wins his third Technique Award. Veteran [[Misugisato]] wins his first (and only) special prize in his career, for Fighting Spirit. Former ''[[sekiwake]]'' [[Ozutsu Takeshi|Ozutsu]] and [[Tochitsukasa]], and former ''[[komusubi]]'' [[Takanofuji]], all retire. Another former ''sekiwake'', [[Kotogaume]], wins the ''juryo'' championship. Former [[Nihon University]] champion [[Higonoumi|Sakamotoyama]] wins the ''[[makushita]]'' division title with a perfect 7-0 record.
===July=== *''Maegashira'' [[Mitoizumi]] is the surprise winner of the championship with a 13-2 record.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/sports/2000/09/16/sumo/former-sekiwake-mitoizumi-retires/#.W2RcgeSWymQ|title=Former sekiwake Mitoizumi retires|date=16 September 2000|publisher=Japam Times|accessdate=3 August 2018}}</ref> He finishes two wins ahead of [[Musashimaru]], who wins his first Technique Award, and ''ozeki'' [[Kirishima Kazuhiro|Kirishima]] on 11-4. Mitoizumi also receives his sixth Fighting Spirit prize. The Outstanding Performance prize goes to [[Kyokudozan]] for defeating the two highest ranked wrestlers on the ''banzuke'' (Kirishima and Konishiki). The ''juryo'' championship goes to [[Wakashoyo]]. Former ''maegashira'' [[Wakasegawa]] retires.
===September=== *Takahanada wins his second championship with a 14–1 record from the rank of [[komusubi]]. He also wins his fourth Outstanding Performance prize. His closest challengers are two maegashira, [[Kotonishiki]] and [[Daishoho]], both on 11-4. Daishoho shares the Fighting Spirit prize with [[Kyokudozan]], who gets a [[kachi-koshi|winning record]] in his komusubi debut. [[Kotobeppu]] wins the juryo championship, while 28 year old ex-teacher and amateur champion [[Tomonohana|Narimatsu]] wins the makushita championship. [[Izutsu stable]]'s [[Sakahoko]] and [[Sasshunada]] both retire.
===November=== *Akebono wins his second championship. [[Kirishima Kazuhiro|Kirishima]] loses his ''ozeki'' status.
==See also== *[[List of years in sumo]]
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Years in sumo}}
[[Category:Years in sumo]] [[Category:1992 in sports|Sumo]]
{{sumo-stub}}

{{Infobox games| |Name=17th Summer Deaflympics |Logo= |Optional caption= |Motto= |Host city=[[Sofia]],{{BUL}} |Nations participating=52 countries |Athletes participating=1679 athletes |Events=126 (14 disciplines) |Opening ceremony=24 July 1993 |Closing ceremony=2 August 1993 |Officially opened by= |Torch lighter= |Stadium=}} '''The 1993 Summer Deaflympics''' officially known as the '''17th Summer Deaflympics''' is an international multi-sport event that was held from 24 July 1993 to 2 August 1993. The event was hosted by [[Sofia]], [[Bulgaria]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.deaflympics.com/games.asp?1993-s|title=Games {{!}}1993 Summer Deaflympics|last=|first=|date=|website=www.deaflympics.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-11-16}} More than 50 nations participated in the multi-sporting event and this was also the first instance where more than 50 nations competed in a single Deaflympic event. The Summer Games included 12 different sports. Sofia was selected to host the Deaflympic event for the first time and after 20 years, the city went onto host the Summer Deaflympics competition in [[2013 Summer Deaflympics|2013]]. In fact, [[Sofia]] became only the second city in the world to have hosted the Summer Deaflympics event twice after [[Copenhagen]]. == References == {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-bef|before=[[1989 Summer Deaflympics|1989]]
XVI
Christchurch, New Zealand}} {{s-ttl|title=1993 Summer Deaflympics|years= XVII

Copenhagen, Denmark}} {{s-end}} {{Deaflympics}} {{Bulgaria-sport-stub}} [[Category:1993 in multi-sport events]] [[Category:1993 in Bulgarian sport]] [[Category:July 1993 sports events]] [[Category:August 1993 sports events]] [[Category:International sports competitions hosted by Bulgaria]] [[Category:1990s in Sofia]] [[Category:Sports competitions in Sofia]] [[Category:Disabled sport in Bulgaria]] [[Category:Multi-sport events in Bulgaria]] [[Category:Deaflympics]]

revision.text:
[[Image:basketball.png|thumb|right|A typical basketball]] A '''basketball''' is a [[Sphere|spherical]] [[ball]] used in [[basketball]] games. Basketballs typically range in size from very small promotional items only a few inches in diameter to extra large balls nearly a foot in diameter used in training exercises. For example, a youth basketball could be {{convert|27|in|cm}} in circumference, while a [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] (NCAA) men's ball would be a maximum of {{convert|30|in|cm}} and an NCAA women's ball would be a maximum of {{convert|29|in|cm}}. The standard for a basketball in the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA) is {{convert|29.5|in|cm}} in [[circumference]] and for the [[Women's National Basketball Association]] (WNBA), a maximum circumference of {{convert|29|in|cm}}. High school and junior leagues normally use NCAA, NBA or WNBA sized balls.{{Cite web|url=http://www.stack.com/a/basketball-sizes |title=Basketball Sizes: A Quick Guide for All Levels of Play|last=Zirm|first=Jordan|website=STACK|language=en|access-date=2017-05-05}}{{cite web|url=https://www.livestrong.com/article/84284-basketball-official-size-weight/|title=Basketball Official Size & Weight|first=Carl|last=Putman|date=September 11, 2017|website=LiveStrong.com|access-date=2018-02-02}} Aside from the court and the baskets, the basketball is the only piece of equipment necessary to play the game of basketball. During the game, the ball must be bounced continuously ([[Basketball#Dribbling|dribbling]]), thrown through the air to other players ([[Basketball#Passing|passing]]) or thrown towards the basket ([[Basketball#Shooting|shooting]]). Therefore, the ball must be very durable and easy to hold on to. The ball is also used to perform tricks (sometimes called freestyling), the most common of which are spinning the ball on the tip of one's middle finger, dribbling in complex patterns, rolling the ball over one's shoulder, or performing aerobatic maneuvers with the ball while executing a [[slam dunk]], most notably in the context of a [[Slam Dunk Contest|slam dunk contest]]. ==Characteristics== Nearly all basketballs have an inflatable inner [[rubber]] bladder, generally wrapped in layers of fiber and then covered with a surface made either from [[leather]] (traditional), rubber, or a synthetic composite. As in most inflatable balls, there is a small opening that allows the pressure to be increased or decreased. The surface of the ball is nearly always divided by "ribs" that are recessed below the surface of the ball in a variety of configurations and are generally a contrasting [[color]]. A brownish orange surface with [[black]] ribs and a possible logo is the traditional color scheme of basketballs but they are sold in various colors. Balls are generally designated for indoor (generally made of leather or absorbent composites), or all-surface use (generally made of rubber or durable composites, also known as indoor/outdoor balls). Indoor balls tend to be considerably more expensive than all-surface balls due to cost of materials. In addition, brand new all-leather indoor balls must be "broken in" first to achieve optimal grip before use in competition. The abrasiveness of asphalt and the dirt and moisture present in an outdoor setting will usually ruin an indoor ball within a very short period of time, which is why an indoor/outdoor ball is recommended for recreational players. Outdoor balls are commonly made from rubber to cope with rougher conditions, and they need to be filled with more air to retain a suitable level of air pressure in colder weather.{{cite web |url=http://www.sportsgearlab.com/best-outdoor-basketball/ |title=Sports Gear Lab |publisher=Sportsgearlab.com |accessdate=31 May 2016}} ==Sizes== Different sizes are used for different age groups.{{Cite web|url=https://www.breakthroughbasketball.com/basketballs/size-chart.html|title=Basketball Size Chart - Recommended Sizes for Mom & Me |website=www.breakthroughbasketball.com|access-date=2017-05-05}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fiba.basketball/OBR2017/BasketballEquipment/Final.pdf |title=Rule 7: Basketballs |work=Official Basketball Rules 2017: Basketball Equipment |pages=11–12 |publisher=FIBA |date=4 July 2017 |accessdate=30 September 2017}} The common standards are: {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- !Size || Type || Circumference || Weight || Notes on basketball |- | 7 || Men || {{cvt|29.5|in|cm}}
[{{cvt|749|–|780|mm|in|1|disp=br}}] || {{cvt|22|oz|g}}
[{{cvt|567|–|650|g|oz|0|disp=br}}] || style="text-align:left;" | Men and boys ages 15 and up. This is the official size for men's high school, college, and professional. |- | 6 || Women || {{cvt|28.5|in|cm}}
[{{cvt|724|–|737|mm|in|1|disp=br}}] || {{cvt|20|oz|g}}
[{{cvt|510|–|567|g|oz|0|disp=br}}] || style="text-align:left;" | Boys ages 12-14. Women and girls ages 12 and up. This is the official size for women’s high school, college, and professional. |- | 5 || Youth (North America)
Mini (FIBA) || {{cvt|27.5|in|cm}}
[{{cvt|690|–|710|mm|in|1|disp=br}}] || {{cvt|17|oz|g}}
[{{cvt|470|–|500|g|oz|0|disp=br}}] || style="text-align:left;" | Boys and girls ages 9-11 years old. This is the standard youth basketball. |- | 4 || Youth (North America) || {{cvt|25.5|in|cm}} || {{cvt|14|oz|g}} || style="text-align:left;" | Boys and girls ages 5-8 years old. |- | 3 || Mini (North America) || {{cvt|22.0|in|cm}} || {{cvt|10|oz|g}} || style="text-align:left;" | Boys and girls ages 4-8 years old. Also known as “mini” basketball. |} Note that the ball used for all competitions (men's, women's, and mixed) in the formalized halfcourt game of [[3x3 (basketball)|3x3]] combines characteristics of the size 6 and size 7 balls. Its circumference is that of a size 6 ball, but its weight is that of a size 7.{{cite press release|url=http://www.amersports.com/newsroom/archive/news-article/2015/06/09/wilson-to-provide-the-official-game-ball-for-fiba |title=Wilson to provide the Official Game Ball for FIBA |publisher=[[Amer Sports]] |date=9 June 2015 |accessdate=17 August 2015}} ==History== [[Image:Basketball historic.tif|thumb|right|A historic basketball.]] In early December 1891, the chairman of the physical education department at the School for Christian Workers (now Springfield College) in [[Springfield, Massachusetts]], Canadian instructed physical education teacher [[James Naismith]], known to many as the inventor of basketball, to invent a new game to entertain the school's athletes in the winter season. Naismith assembled his class of 18 young men, appointed captains of two nine-player teams, and set in motion the first ever basketball game, played with a soccer ball and two peach baskets tacked to either end of the gymnasium. The first purpose-built basketballs were made from panels of leather stitched together with a rubber bladder inside. A cloth lining was added to the leather for support and uniformity (identity). A molded version of the early basketball was invented in 1942. For many years, leather was the material of choice for basketball coverings, however in the late 1990s, composite materials, like synthetics were put forth and have rapidly gained acceptance in most leagues due to their superior performance in harsh outdoor game conditions. From 1967 through 1976, the [[American Basketball Association (1967-1976)|American Basketball Association]] (ABA) used a distinctive red, white and blue basketball that is still seen from time to time. ==Notable basketball manufacturers== {| |- |'''Spalding''' |- |[[Image:Spalding-Platinum-ZKPro.jpg|150px]] |[[Spalding (sports equipment)|Spalding]] was the first company to produce a basketball for official use. Company founder [[Albert Spalding|A.G. Spalding]] made the first dedicated basketball in the last years of the 19th century at the behest of James Naismith. It has produced basketballs since that time and has produced the NBA’s official game ball since 1983. They also produce the basketballs for the WNBA and [[NBA Development League]]. The company also produces a wide variety of balls for the consumer market. In 2012, it also became official provider for both the [[Euroleague]] and [[Eurocup Basketball|Eurocup]] competitions.[http://www.euroleaguebasketball.net/euroleague-basketball/news/i/100466/spalding-becomes-global-provider-for-euroleague-basketball Spalding becomes global provider for Euroleague Basketball] It also serves as provider for [[Liga ACB]]. Spalding became the new supplier for [[National Basketball League (Australia)|NBL Australia]] in 2010.{{cite web| url=http://basketball.net.au/basketball-australia-to-play-ball-with-spalding-through-to-2019/ |title=Basketball Australia to Play Ball with Spalding Through to 2019 |date=August 10, 2016 |website=Basketball Australia |accessdate=2018-02-02}} |- |'''Molten''' |- |[[Image:Molten GL7.jpg|150px]] |[[Molten Corporation|Molten]], a Japanese sporting goods manufacturer, has the current contract to provide game balls for:{{cn|date=February 2018}} *All [[International Basketball Federation]] (FIBA) world championships and continental qualifying events. *All [[FIBA Asia]] events. *The [[VTB United League]]. *Many domestic leagues, including NBL Australia, [[Liga Nacional de Básquetbol|Argentina]], [[Liga Uruguaya de Basketball|Uruguay]], [[British Basketball League]], [[Ligue féminine de basket|France]] (women), [[Greek Basket League|Greece]], [[National Basketball League (Indonesia)|Indonesia]], [[Lega Basket Serie A|Italy]], [[Lietuvos Krepšinio Lyga|Lithuania]], [[Philippine Basketball Association|the Philippines]], [[PLKK|Poland (women's)]], and [[Portuguese Basketball League (LCB)|Portugal]].{{cn|date=February 2018}} Until the 2006–07 season, it had provided balls for both Europe-wide competitions organized by [[Euroleague Basketball]], the [[Euroleague]] and [[ULEB Eurocup|ULEB Cup]] (now the Eurocup).{{cn|date=February 2018}} Molten's top-of-the line product is the GL7, a leather ball with a distinctive 12-panel design.{{cite web |url=http://www.molten-gl7.com/english/index.html |title=GL7 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070419133610/http://www.molten-gl7.com/english/index.html |archive-date=April 19, 2007 }}{{dead link|date=February 2018}} |- |'''Wilson''' |- |[[Image:Wilson Solution.jpg|150px]] |[[Wilson Sporting Goods]] is the official ball supplier of all NCAA postseason tournaments, most notably the [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|men's]] and [[NCAA Women's Division I Basketball Championship|women's]] Division I tournaments, and is used by many NCAA teams during the season as well by many high school leagues. As of 2015, Wilson also supplies balls for all FIBA-operated 3x3 competitions. Like Spalding, Wilson produces a variety of balls for the consumer market as well. |- |'''Rawlings''' |- |[[Image:Rawlings TEN.jpg|150px]] |[[Rawlings (company)|Rawlings]] has manufactured basketballs since 1902. The company is known for producing a 10-panel ball (known as the TEN), along with traditional 8-panel balls. The TEN basketball is the official ball of the [[Amateur Athletic Union]] and the "[[Gus Macker]]", the largest 3-on-3 basketball tournament in the United States.{{cn|date=February 2018}} |- |'''Nike''' |- |[[Image:BB9 4005.jpg|150px]] |[[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] had the contract to produce balls for the [[Euroleague Basketball Company]] (including the Euroleague and the [[Eurocup Basketball|Eurocup]]) from 2007{{cite web |url=http://www.euroleague.net/news/i/13989/180/item |title=Euroleague Basketball Announces Partnership with Nike |publisher=Euroleague Basketball |date=2007-06-28 |accessdate=2007-07-02| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070701155226/http://www.euroleague.net/news/i/13989/180/item| archivedate= 1 July 2007 | deadurl= no}} until 2012, when it turned to Spalding. In the Philippines the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association (Philippines)|NCAA]] and [[University Athletic Association of the Philippines|UAAP]] use the Nike 4005 Official Tournament Balls. |- |'''Nivia''' |- |[[File:Nivia Basketball, Top Grip, BB-195, Jan2017.jpg|150px]] |[[Nivia]] is India's first sports equipment manufacturer produces hand made basketballs. [[Nivia]] was one of the official partners of [[2015 National Games of India]] for [[basketball]]. Former sponsored for Indian College basketball league & Indian school of basketball league. [[Nivia Sports]] makes 1 ball in every 3 seconds, all balls are assured with quality test by shooting them at the speed of 25 mph at an iron plate of thickness of 1 inch for 2000 times before sending them to leagues.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/videos/cnnmoney/2017/04/27/in-the-making-blob-of-rubber-turn-into-basketball-orig.cnnmoney|title=Watch a blob of rubber turn into a basketball|work=CNN}} |- |'''Others''' |- | colspan=2 |Include: [[Adidas]], Avaro, Baden (official [[Harlem Globetrotters]] supplier), [[Dunlop Sport|Dunlop]], [[:zh:上海红双喜股份有限公司|DHS]], [[Decathlon Group|Kipsta]], [[Mikasa Sports|Mikasa]], [[Mitre Sports International|Mitre]], Sterling Athletics.. |} ==See also== *[[List of inflatable manufactured goods]] == References == {{Commons category|Basketball balls}} {{Wiktionary|basketball}} {{reflist}} {{basketball}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Basketball (Ball)}} [[Category:Balls]] [[Category:Basketball equipment]] [[Category:Inflatable manufactured goods]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Dr Pepper Arena & StarCenter | image = File:2018 Lone Star Conference Women's Basketball Championship (Texas A&M–Commerce vs. West Texas A&M) 01.jpg | logo_image = Dr Pepper Arena.jpg | address = 2601 Avenue of the Stars | location = [[Frisco, Texas]] | broke_ground = | opened = 2003 | renovated = 2009 | construction_cost = $ 27 million [[United States dollar|USD]] | renovation_cost = $ 39 million [[United States dollar|USD]] | owner = [[Frisco, Texas|City of Frisco]] | operator = [[Dallas Stars]] | architect = [[Balfour Beatty]]/[[HKS, Inc.]] | surface = Multi-surface | tenants = [[Texas Tornado]] ([[North American Hockey League|NAHL]]) (2003–2013)
[[Dallas Stars]] Practice Facility ([[NHL]]) (2003–present)
[[Dallas Desire]] ([[Legends Football League|LFL]]) (2004–2008, 2016)
[[Frisco Thunder]] ([[Intense Football League|IntenseFL]]) (2007–2008)
[[Texas Legends]] ([[NBA G League]]) (2010–present)
[[Texas Revolution (indoor football)|Texas Revolution]] ([[Champions Indoor Football|CIF]]) (2018–present)
[[World Olympic Gymnastics Academy]] | seating_capacity = [[Ice hockey]]: 3,500
[[Basketball]]: 4,000–4,500
[[Concerts]]: 7,000 (standing room only) |}} The '''Dr Pepper Arena and StarCenter''' is a multi-purpose [[arena]] located in [[Frisco, Texas]] at the corner of the [[Dallas North Tollway]] and Gaylord Ave. It is the home of the [[Texas Legends]] of the [[NBA G League]], the [[Texas Revolution (indoor football)|Texas Revolution]] of [[Champions Indoor Football]],{{cite web | last=Irvine | first=Cameron | |url=http://www.texasrevs.com/texas-revolution-to-celebrate-pro-sports-in-frisco-announce-move-to-dr-pepper-arena-wednesday-aug-30/ |title=Texas Revolution to Celebrate Pro Sports in Frisco, Announce Move to Dr Pepper Arena Wednesday, Aug. 30 |publisher=Texas Revolution |date=August 28, 2017 | access-date=December 10, 2017}} as well as the executive offices and practice facility of the [[National Hockey League]]'s [[Dallas Stars]]. It previously served as the home of the [[Texas Tornado]] team of the [[North American Hockey League]]; the NAHL maintains its headquarters at the arena. The arena is also used for concerts and other live entertainment events. It seats between 5,000 and 7,000 people and has a 2,100-vehicle parking garage.{{Cite web | last=Cohn | first=Justin A. | date=December 10, 2017 | title=Ants staying? Coliseum optimistic | Mad Ants | The Journal Gazette | url=http://www.journalgazette.net/sports/professional/madants/20171210/ants-staying-coliseum-optimistic | website=JournalGazette.net | access-date=December 10, 2017 | quote=Most G League teams play in arenas smaller than the Coliseum with the smallest attendance average this season being the South Bay Lakers' 614 at the Los Angeles Lakes' practice facility, the Toyota Sports Center, and the largest being the Texas Legends' 5,628 at Dr. Pepper Arena.}} The arena's south parking lot has served as the Metroplex venue for some of [[Cirque du Soleil]]'s Grand Chapiteau shows, while the arena itself has served as a Metroplex venue for its arena shows. The [[Dr Pepper Snapple Group]] has held naming rights to the arena since it opened, but the arena was originally known as the '''[[Deja Blue]] Arena''' as Dr Pepper chose to promote its brand of bottled water before its name was changed to Dr Pepper Arena. The Dr Pepper Arena was the former home of the [[Frisco Thunder]] team of the [[Intense Football League]]. A [[Lone Star Football League]] team to be called the [[Frisco Falcons]] was announced for a spring 2012 start but collapsed before the season began. The arena hosted the [[2012 Robertson Cup]] Tournament to decide the champion of the NAHL, with the Texas Tornado ultimately winning the championship. It is the second time the venue has hosted the event. It also hosted the 2013 Robertson Cup with the [[Amarillo Bulls]] winning the championship. On March 23–26, 2016, the Dr Pepper Arena hosted the [[2016 NCAA Division II Men's Basketball Tournament|NCAA Men's Division II Basketball Elite Eight]], which was won by [[Augustana (SD) Vikings|Augustana University]] of South Dakota. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.drpepperarena.com Dr Pepper Arena web site] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090620231314/http://www.nba.com/dleague/frisco/ Frisco NBA Development League team web site] {{Dallas Stars}} {{NBA G League arenas}} {{CIF Arenas}} {{Music venues of Texas}} [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:NBA G League arenas]] [[Category:Texas Legends]] [[Category:Arena football venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Texas]] [[Category:American football venues in the Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex]] [[Category:Keurig Dr Pepper]] [[Category:Music venues in Texas]] [[Category:Sports in Frisco, Texas]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Texas]] [[Category:National Hockey League practice facilities]] [[Category:Northland Properties]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2003]] [[Category:2003 establishments in Texas]] {{coord|33.101026|-96.819624|display=title|type:landmark}}

revision.comment: Animalparty moved page [[East Side, West Side: Tales of New York Sporting Life 1910–1960]] to [[East Side, West Side (book)]]: Per [[WP: SUBTITLES]] and [[WP:CONCISE]]
revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''East Side, West Side: Tales of New York Sporting Life 1910–1960''''' ({{ISBN|0-9656949-6-8}}) is a sports book written by [[Lawrence S. Ritter]] and published in 1998. It is a [[Total Sports Publishing|Total Sports]] production and was distributed by [[Andrews McNeel]].
The book centers, as its title suggests, on popular sports sites and figures of [[New York City|New York]] between 1910 and 1960. Among the personalities the book talks about in depth are [[Babe Ruth]], [[Lou Gehrig]], [[Joe Louis]], [[Primo Carnera]], [[Tony Canzoneri]], [[Sugar Ray Robinson]], [[Casey Stengel]], [[Mickey Mantle]], [[Joe DiMaggio]], [[Lou Stillman]], [[Jacob Ruppert]] and more. Sports covered in depth are [[baseball]], [[basketball]], [[boxing]], [[ice hockey|hockey]] and [[horse racing]], all of which were popular sports in New York during the 50 years covered by the book.
{{DEFAULTSORT:East Side, West Side: Tales of New York Sporting Life 1910-1960}} [[Category:1992 books]] [[Category:Books about sports]] [[Category:Sports in New York City]]

{{Infobox football club |clubname=Tertons |image=FC_Tertons_Logo.png |fullname=Football Club Terton |nickname= |founded={{start date and age|2014}} |ground=[[Changlimithang Stadium|Changlimithang]]
[[Thimphu]], [[Bhutan]] |coordinates= |capacity=40,000 |head coach=[[Pema]] |league=[[Bhutan National League]] |season=[[2015 Bhutan National League|2015]] |position =1st | }} '''F.C. Tertons''' are a [[Association football|football]] club from [[Thimphu]], [[Bhutan]] who compete in B-Division of Bhutan football league. ==History== Terton made their debut in the [[2015_Bhutan_National_League#Thimphu_League|2015 Thimphu League]], which they won by three points from [[Thimphu F.C.|Thimphu]], collecting the [[Ngultrum|Nu]] 400,000 first prize and qualifying for the [[2015_Bhutan_National_League#National_League|2015 Bhutan National League]]. During their inaugural season in the Thimphu League, they lost only twice; a 3–5 defeat to [[Druk Star F.C.|Druk Star]] and a 1–3 loss to eventual runners-up Thimphu.{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesb/bhutan2015.html|title=Bhutan 2015|last=Stokkermans|first=Karel|last2=Jigmi|first2=Sonam|date=23 July 2015|website=www.rsssf.com|publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation]]|accessdate=27 July 2015}} They were equally successful in their debut season in the National League, beating [[Thimphu City F.C.|Thimphu City]] 4–2 in the final game to confirm the championship, collecting the Nu 10 million first place prize and qualifying for the [[2017 AFC Cup]]. ===Continental history=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Season ! Competition ! Round ! Club ! Home ! Away ! Aggregate |- |rowspan="4"|[[2017 AFC Cup|2017]] |rowspan="4"|[[AFC Cup]] |rowspan="4"|[[2017 AFC Cup qualifying round|Qualifying]] |{{flagicon|TPE}} [[Tatung F.C.|Tatung]] | colspan=3; style="text-align:center;"|0–0 |- |{{flagicon|BAN}} [[Sheikh Russel KC|Sheikh Russel]] | colspan=3; style="text-align:center;"|4–3 |} ==Honours== *'''[[Thimphu League]]''' – one time winners: ::[[2015_Bhutan_National_League#Thimphu_League|2015]]{{cite web |url=http://www.kuenselonline.com/yanmar-thimphu-league-kicks-off-today/ |title=Yanmar Thimphu league kicks off today |last1=Tshedup |first1=Younten|date=4 April 2015 |website=www.kuenselonline.com |publisher=[[Kuensel]] |access-date=24 September 2015}} *'''[[Bhutan National League]]''' – one time winners: ::[[2015_Bhutan_National_League#National_League|2015]]{{cite web |url=http://www.kuenselonline.com/fc-terton-is-bob-national-league-champions/ |title=FC Terton is BoB national league champions |last1=Tshedup |first1=Younten|date=24 September 2015 |website=www.kuenselonline.com |publisher=[[Kuensel]] |access-date=24 September 2015}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Bhutan National League}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Terton, F.C.}} [[Category:Football clubs in Bhutan]] [[Category:Sport in Bhutan]] {{Bhutan-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox sport tournament |year = 2009 |name = Fortissimus |image = FortissimusLogo.jpg |caption = The official logo of Fortissimus |location = [[Notre-Dame-du-Rosaire (2008) Montmagny (2009), Quebec|Montmagny]], [[Quebec]] [[Canada]] |establishment = 2008 |format = Multi-event competition |purse = |final_year= 2009 |final_champion = {{flagicon|LTU}} [[Zydrunas Savickas]] }}
The '''Fortissimus''' is a defunct event in [[strength athletics]]. The name means "the mightiest"<ref name="Milo08"/> and was a multi-event challenge at the end of which the winner is crowned as the "Strongest Man on Earth". It was set up to bring together the strongest competitors on the planet independent of the organisations to which they were signed, and also as a tribute to the nineteenth-century Canadian strongman [[Louis Cyr]], which gave it many similarities to [[Le Defi Mark Ten International]] which last took place in Canada in the early 1990s. After its first airing in 2008, the strength athletics magazine Milo described it as the ultimate strongman competition ever held.<ref name="Milo08">Kristin Nelson, ''Milo'', ''Fortissimus: A mighty challenge - a magnificent win'', September 2008, Vol 16, No2</ref> Despite a successful edition in 2009, a reported lack of a major sponsor for 2010 resulted in the competition being suspended, no future contests have been announced.<ref name="CWS suspend">[http://www.ironmind.com/ironmind/opencms/Articles/2009/Dec/Canada_World_Strength-No_Strongman_Contest_in_2010.html Randall J. Strossen, ''Canada World Strength: No Strongman Contest in 2010'', Friday, December 11, 2009, IronMind]</ref>
==History== The world of strength athletics in 2008 was fragmented, with a number of individuals being able to lay claim to be the strongest in the world by virtue of having won mutually exclusive events. Athletes affiliated to [[IFSA Strongman]] were not allowed to compete in the [[World's Strongest Man]] ("WSM"), which is produced by [[Trans World International|TWI]] and thus neither the WSM and its associated [[WSM Super Series]] nor the IFSA circuit can claim to have a comprehensive field of the top athletes. Some events did exist that bridged the divide between the major organisations, such as the [[Arnold Strongman Classic]]. Fortissimus was to be another such bridge but with a difference. The driving force behind the event, Paul Ohl, is one of the world's leading authorities on the great Louis Cyr, the nineteenth century strongman and want to create a competition to honour this man, said to have been the strongest man in the world. Fortissimus was set up to be the all-inclusive strength and power package to demonstrate ''"the essence of the sport of strongman is the multi-disciplinary array of tests of global strength, resulting from a combination of static (brute) strength, overall explosive power and power grip, strength athletics mastery, endurance and stamina"''. The concept was to link with the tradition of strongman and to honor the memory and deeds of the great Louis Cyr. Ten events, called the Classical Events, were incorporated into the programme.
The night before Day 1 of the 2008 event the athletes were honoured at a banquet hosted by Paul Ohl and was attended by the townspeople of [[Notre-Dame-du-Rosaire, Quebec|Notre-Dame-du-Rosaire]], where the event was being held, and the mayor of that town. Mayor Carl Dubé welcomed the athletes to Notre Dame du Rosaire in June 2008 and thousands of spectators flocked to see many of the world’s top strongmen perform, including [[Zydrunas Savickas]], [[Derek Poundstone]], [[Andrus Murumets]], [[Travis Ortmayer]] and [[Mikhail Koklyaev]]. The event was lauded across the strongman world, with the likes of Ironmind and Milo magazine praising it. So popular was it that a three-year deal with the Regional Community of [[Montmagny, Quebec]] was soon struck with the newly formed Fortissimus World Strength board. Derek Poundstone won the event in spectacular fashion. With the final event left, the Natural Stones of Strength, [[Zydrunas Savickas]] was 5 points clear of Poundstone. The three huge stone in the event were the 350 lb Bill Kazmaier stone, the 400 lb Paul Anderson stone and the giant 517 lb Louis Cyr stone.<ref name="Milo08"/> The winner would be the best time or most stones loaded. Some of the athletes lifted one stone, others the second. When it came to the third, the Cyr stone that only Louis Cyr had previously lifted over a century before, most athletes passed on it. Some touched it but did not attempt to lift it.<ref name="Milo08"/> [[Zydrunas Savickas]], having lifted the first two in an astonishing 8.8 seconds, tried the Cyr stone but managed to lift it just one inch before deciding it was too much. Poundstone took 11 seconds over the first two stones, significantly quicker than all others except Savickas. Savickas is reported to have raised his hands in victory at seeing this time.<ref name="Milo08"/> However, his celebration was to have been premature. To the astonishment of the athletes, the crowd and even the organisers, Poundstone managed to move the stone. Screams of amazement were said to have come from the crowd. Inch by inch he raised the stone and eventually placed it on the platform. Later, Paul Ohl was to say to Derek Poundstone ''"You know, you weren't supposed to lift that stone. I put it in the competition as a tribute to Louis Cyr. Whoever is able to lift that stone would be considered an heir to Louis Cyr."''<ref name="Milo08"/> Having lifted the fabled Cyr stone, Poundstone had the honour of having his name added to the stone, being the only man other than Cyr to lift the giant weight.<ref name="Fort"/>
One of Paul Ohl's key strengths is his ability to involve the local community, including the regional press, to increase the presence of the event. The 2009 competition saw Marcel Catellier, the chief commissioner of the Regional Community of Montmagny, as chairman of the board, in charge of the general administration of the new corporation and Paul Ohl as president of the event.<ref>Randall J. Strossen, Ph.D., ''Fortissimus 2009 . . . 2010 . . .2011'', Ironmind, December 22, 2008</ref>
[[Zydrunas Savickas]] reversed the results of 2008, where he came second, to clinch the title in 2009, with Poundstone coming second. Prior to the event, to further enhance the events standing a pre-tournament competition was held, the [[World Championship Rolling Thunder]] on June 26, an event which determined which athlete has the greatest grip strength in the world. [[Mark Felix]] successfully defended his title in this event.<ref name="Fort"/>
The 2010 edition was suspended. Canada World Strength noted in a formal statement: ''"Since the precondition for the holding of a third edition resided mainly in the arrival of a major sponsor by early December and that this condition has not been reached, the organizers have no choice but to [suspend] the 2010 edition."''<ref name="CWS suspend"/> However, the door was held open for 2011 with the statement continuing: ''"“The Board, however, does not abandon the idea of holding a third edition in 2011."''.<ref name="CWS suspend"/>
===Strongman Champions League Cooperation=== In 2008 Paul Ohl stated that the [[Strongman Champions League]] was one of three organisations that had made an agreement with Fortissimus in order to unite the world strength community, the others being the [[American Strongman Corporation]], and the [[Aussiepower]] organization. Within the agreement, Fortissimus, the competition that confers the title of "Strongest Man on the Planet", guaranteed that the winner of the [[America's Strongest Man]] title would be granted a slot in Fortissimus from 2009, as would the winner of the [[Australia's Strongest Man]] title. The agreement with the Strongman Champions League went further, stating that the top three athletes would have guaranteed places and in return the top Canadian athletes would have guaranteed selected participation in the Champions League.<ref>[http://74.205.126.46/ironmind/opencms/Articles/2008/May/Fortissimus_Enters_Agreement_with_Strongman_Champions_League_the_American_Strongman_Corporation_and_Aussiepower.html Fortissimus Enters Agreement with Strongman Champions League, the American Strongman Corporation and Aussiepower by Randall J. Strossen, Ph.D. 2009 IronMind Friday, May 16, 2008 ]</ref> This later went further, guaranteeing the SCL its top five athletes would have places.<ref name="IMJan09"/> The agreement was reemphasised in a joint statement from Marcel Mostert and Paul Ohl in early 2009.<ref name="IMJan09">[http://www.ironmind.com/ironmind/opencms/Articles/2009/Jan/FORTISSIMUS_-_Strongman_Champions_League_Cooperation_and_Joint_Statement.html FORTISSIMUS - Strongman Champions League: Cooperation and Joint Statement by Randall J. Strossen, Ph.D. 2009 IronMind, Tuesday, January 13, 2009]</ref>
==Events== Fortissimus regards the ten events that are incorporated in its programme as the Classical Events of strength athletics.
*The LOG LIFT *The DEADLIFT (modified version from Powerlifting) *The YOKE *The FARMER (FERGUS) POWER WALK *The ATLAS (McGLASHEN) STONES LIFT *The NATURAL STONES OF STRENGTH LIFT *The HUSAFELL STONE CARRY (and related) *The APOLLON AXLE LIFT *The ONE-ARM DUMBBELL LIFT (Louis Cyr style) *The PYRAMID WEIGHT LIFT (Power stairs) *The BACK LIFT
==Trophy== From 2009 Fortissimus established that the title of the champion would be "The Strongest Man on Earth". The winner’s trophy is a bronze statuette of Louis Cyr hoisting the huge 273 ¼ lbs dumbbell that brought him fame on the evening of 19 January 1892 at London’s [[Royal Aquarium]]. It was crafted by renowned Canadian sculptor Michel Binette with the original displayed at the [[Inverness Bronze Museum]], in [[Inverness, Quebec]], Canada.<ref name="Fort">[http://www.fortissimus.ca/pages/index_e.aspx?DetailID=183 Official Sire]</ref>
==Results==
===2008=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! # ! Name ! Nationality ! Pts |- |- style="background:gold;" |1 | [[Derek Poundstone]] | {{flagicon|USA}} | 119 |- |- style="background:silver;" |2 | [[Zydrunas Savickas]] | {{flagicon|LTU}} | 118 |- |- style="background:#c96;" |3 | [[Sebastian Wenta]] | {{flagicon|POL}} | 84.25 |- |4 | [[Louis-Philippe Jean]] | {{flagicon|CAN}} | 83.5 |- |5 | [[Travis Ortmayer]] | {{flagicon|USA}} | 76.5 |- |6 | [[Mikhaïl Koklyaev]] | {{flagicon|RUS}} | 76.5 |- |7 | [[Mark Felix]] | {{flagicon|GBR}} | 67.5 |- |8 | [[Stefan Solvi Petursson]] | {{flagicon|ISL}} | 63.75 |- |9 | [[Andrus Murumets]] | {{flagicon|EST}} | 62 |- |10 | [[Christian Savoie]] | {{flagicon|CAN}} | 42.5 |- |11 | [[Arild Haugen]] | {{flagicon|NOR}} | 40.5 |- |12 | [[Ervin Katona]] | {{flagicon|SER}} | 36.5 |- |13 | [[Dominic Filiou]] | {{flagicon|CAN}} | 25.5 |- |}
''Source for the above:<ref name="Milo08"/>''
===2009=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! # ! Name ! Nationality ! Pts |- |- style="background:gold;" |1 | [[Zydrunas Savickas]] | {{flagicon|LTU}} | 124.5 |- |- style="background:silver;" |2 | [[Derek Poundstone]] | {{flagicon|USA}} | 118 |- |- style="background:#c96;" |3 | [[Brian Shaw (strongman)|Brian Shaw]] | {{flagicon|USA}} | 106.5 |- |4 | [[Travis Ortmayer]] | {{flagicon|USA}} | 94 |- |5 | [[Mikhaïl Koklyaev]] | {{flagicon|RUS}} | 84 |- |6 | [[Phil Pfister]] | {{flagicon|USA}} | 82 |- |7 | [[Andrus Murumets]] | {{flagicon|EST}} | 74 |- |8 | [[Louis-Philippe Jean]] | {{flagicon|CAN}} | 73.5 |- |9 | [[Terry Hollands]] | {{flagicon|GBR}} | 55.5 |- |10 | [[Mark Felix]] | {{flagicon|GBR}} | 54 |- |11 | [[Christian Savoie]] | {{flagicon|CAN}} | 49 |- |12 | [[Agris Kazelniks]] | {{flagicon|LAT}} | 47 |- |13 | [[Jimmy Marku]] | {{flagicon|GBR}} | 32 |- |14 | [[Derek Boyer]] | {{flagicon|FIJ}}/{{flagicon|AUS}} | 24 |- |} ''Source for the above:<ref name="Fort"/>''
==Fortissimus Strongman of the Year== This is not the Fortissimus competition title but a recognition of the achievements of a particular strongman over the previous year.
===2008=== {{flagicon|POL}} [[ Mariusz Pudzianowski ]]<ref>http://www.ironmind.com/ironmind/opencms/Articles/2009/Feb/Mariusz_Pudzianowski_Wins_2008_Fortissimus_Strongman_Achievement_of_the_Year_Award.html</ref>
===2009=== {{flagicon|LTU}} [[Zydrunas Savickas]]<ref>http://www.ironmind.com/ironmind/opencms/Articles/2009/Feb/Zydrunas_Savickas_Wins_Fortissimus_Strongman_of_the_Year_Award.html</ref>
==Fortissimus Lifetime Achievement Award== The Fortissimus Lifetime Achievement Award is given to recognize the greatest strongman athletes in the history of the sport, both past and present athletes are eligible for this title.
===2009=== {{flagicon|ISL}} [[Magnus Ver Magnusson]]<ref>[http://www.ironmind.com/ironmind/opencms/Articles/2009/May/Magnus_Ver_Magnusson_Wins_2009_FORTISSIMUS_Strongman_Lifetime_Achievement_Award.html Ironmind report Friday, May 1, 2009]</ref>
==References== <references/> http://fitq.co.uk/
==External links== *[http://www.fortissimus.ca Official Site of Fortissimus]

/* Sporting events */
revision.text:
{{Infobox venue | name = Hanns-Martin-Schleyer-Halle | nickname = Schleyer-Halle | fullname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = [[File:Schleyerhalle-West.jpg|220px]] | caption = Hanns-Martin-Schleyer-Halle | location = [[Stuttgart]], [[Baden-Wurttemberg]], [[Germany]] | coordinates = {{coord|48|47|38|N|9|13|37|E|region:DE-BW_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 14 September 1983 | renovated = 2005–2006 | expanded = 2006 | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = in.Stuttgart Veranstaltungsgesellschaft mbH | surface = Cycling track: wood | scoreboard = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 15,500 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = {{convert|286|m|yd|abbr=on}} cycling track | acreage = | tenants = | former_names = | estimated_cost = | executive_suites = }} '''Hanns-Martin-Schleyer-Halle''' (sometimes shortened to '''Schleyer-Halle''') is an [[indoor arena]] located in [[Stuttgart]], [[Germany]]. The capacity of the arena is 15,500 people. The venue was built in 1983 and is named for [[Hanns Martin Schleyer]], a German former [[Schutzstaffel]] officer and [[Employers' organization|employer representative]], who was kidnapped and killed by the terrorist group [[Red Army Faction]]. It has a {{convert|265|m|adj=on}} track made of wood. ==Sporting events== The arena hosted the final phase of the [[EuroBasket 1985|1985]] [[EuroBasket|European basketball championship]].[http://www.acb.com/redaccion.php?id=26815 Partidos Históricos: España - Checoslovaquia, semifinal del Eurobasket'85] In tennis, the arena hosts some of the matches of [[Porsche Tennis Grand Prix]], on a clay court designated as "Court 1". It also hosted the [[Madrid Open (tennis)|Stuttgart Masters]] when it was an [[ATP Super 9]] event between 1996 and 2001. The arena is also used as a velodrome and was used as the host for the [[2003 UCI Track Cycling World Championships]]. The [[1989 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships]] and [[2007 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships]] were held at the Hanns-Martin-Schleyer-Hall. ==Concerts== [[Depeche Mode]] performed at the stadium seven times: the first one was on November 2, 1987 during their [[Music for the Masses Tour]]. The second one was on October 15, 1990 during their [[World Violation Tour]]. The third one was on June 25, 1993 during their [[Devotional Tour]]. The fourth one was on September 23, 1998 during their [[The Singles Tour|Singles Tour]]. The fifth one was on October 3, 2001 during their [[Exciter Tour]]. The sixth one was on March 9, 2006 during their [[Touring the Angel]]. The seventh one was on November 8, 2009 during their [[Tour of the Universe (tour)|Tour of the Universe]]. On 11 April 2002, Irish vocal pop band [[Westlife]] held a concert for their [[World of Our Own Tour]] supporting their album [[World of Our Own]]. In July 2009 [[Elton John]] gave a sold out concert in the Schleyerhalle.[http://www.stimme.de/suedwesten/nachrichten/vm/Musik-Pop-Elton-John-spielt-seine-groessten-Hits-in-Stuttgart;art19068,1589686] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Hanns-Martin-Schleyer-Halle}} *{{Official website|http://www.schleyerhalle.de/}} {{de icon}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130101000000/http://www.fixedgearfever.com/modules.php?name=Velodromes&op=showtrack&id=680 {{PAGENAMEBASE}} information] at ''FixedGearFever.com'' {{s-start}} {{succession box | title=[[FIBA EuroBasket]]
Final Venue| before=[[Palais des Sports de Beaulieu]]
[[Nantes]]| after=[[Peace and Friendship Stadium]]
[[Athens]]| years=[[EuroBasket 1985|1985]] }} {{succession box | title=[[Davis Cup]]
Final Venue | before=[[Scandinavium]]
[[Gothenburg]] | after=[[Tropicana Field|Suncoast Dome]]
[[St. Petersburg, Florida|St. Petersburg]] | years=[[1989 Davis Cup|1989]] }} {{succession box | title=[[UCI Track Cycling World Championships]]
Venue| before=[[Green Dome Maebashi]]
[[Maebashi]] | after=[[Luis Puig Velodrome]]
[[Valencia, Spain|Valencia]]| years=[[1991 UCI Track Cycling World Championships|1991]] }} {{succession box | title=UCI Track Cycling World Championships
Venue| before=[[Ballerup Super Arena|Siemens Arena]]
[[Ballerup]] | after=[[Vodafone Arena]]
[[Melbourne]]| years=[[2003 UCI Track Cycling World Championships|2003]] }} {{s-end}} {{Music venues in Germany|collapsed}} [[Category:Indoor arenas in Germany]] [[Category:Sport in Stuttgart]] [[Category:Handball venues in Germany]] [[Category:Velodromes in Germany]] [[Category:Cycle racing in Germany]] [[Category:Indoor track and field venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Baden-Württemberg]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Stuttgart]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1983]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Germany]] [[Category:1983 establishments in West Germany]] {{cycling-venue-stub}} {{Germany-sports-venue-stub}} {{BadenWürttemberg-struct-stub}}

revision.comment: /* Renovations */ add a couple citations
revision.text:
{{Infobox venue | name = Howard J. Lamade Stadium | nickname = Lamade Stadium | image = [[Image:Little League World Series and Lamade Stadium.JPG|250px]] | fullname = | location = [[South Williamsport, Pennsylvania]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = [[1959 in sports|1959]], {{Time ago|1959}} | renovated = 1968 (concrete)
1992 (lights)
2006 (dimensions) | expanded = 1971{{cite web |url=https://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2014/08/04/In-Depth/Timeline.aspx |title=Running the bases: Looking back at 75 years of Little League |website=sportsbusinessdaily.com |date=August 4, 2014 |accessdate=August 21, 2018}} | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Little League Baseball]] | operator = | surface = [[Poa pratensis|Kentucky Bluegrass]] | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = Howard J. Lamade Memorial Field | tenants = [[Little League World Series]] | capacity = 8,000–10,000 (40,000+ with surrounding berms) | dimensions = Any area: {{convert|225|ft|m|1|abbr=on}} | scoreboard = Daktronics BA-2026 }} '''Howard J. Lamade Stadium''' (pronounced "LAM-a-day") is a [[Baseball park|baseball stadium]] in [[South Williamsport, Pennsylvania]]. Each year, along with [[Little League Volunteer Stadium]], it hosts the [[Little League World Series]]. The [[Baseball field|playing field]] is two-thirds the size of a [[professional baseball]] field, with {{convert|60|ft|1|sing=on}} basepaths, a {{convert|46|ft|0|sing=on}} mound, and after modification in 2006, outfield fences at {{convert|225|ft|1|abbr=on}}, forming one-fourth of a true [[circle]]. Stadium seating capacity is 8,000 to 10,000, much of which is bench seating, while large [[berm]]s surrounding the stadium provide additional seating allowing over 40,000 spectators.{{cite web |url=http://www.espn.com/sports/llws13/story/_/id/9550942/little-league-world-series-venues |title=Little League World Series Venues |website=[[ESPN]] |date=August 12, 2013 |accessdate=August 21, 2018}} ==History== Originally called '''Howard J. Lamade Memorial Field''', the ballpark opened for the {{llwsy|1959}} tournament. Howard J. Lamade was the son of ''[[Grit (newspaper)|Grit]]'' newspaper founder Dietrick Lamade.{{cite web |url=https://ballparkdigest.com/201007072894/college-baseball/visits/ballpark-visit-howard-lamade-stadium-little-league-world-series |title=Howard Lamade Stadium / Little League World Series |first=Kevin |last=Reichard |website=ballparkdigest.com |date=July 7, 2010 |accessdate=August 21, 2018}} The younger Lamade was a vice president at Grit Publishing, and served on the board of directors for [[Little League Baseball]] in the 1950s. A donation from Grit Publishing was used to purchase land where the stadium is located. The ballpark received its current name in 1968, when the original wood and steel stands were replaced with a concrete stadium.{{cite web |url=https://www.littleleague.org/news/howard-j-lamade-stadium-named-2018-field-distinction/ |title=Howard J. Lamade Stadium Named 2018 Field of Distinction |website=littleleague.org |date=February 20, 2018 |accessdate=August 20, 2018}} ===Renovations=== [[File:Exterior of Howard J. Lamade Stadium.jpg|thumb|right|The exterior of Lamade Stadium in 2007]] Lights were added in 1992 to facilitate night game play in conjunction with expansion of the series to [[Round-robin tournament|round robin]] play.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=G7wjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=rNAFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5394%2C784828 |newspaper=[[Moscow-Pullman Daily News]] |agency=Associated Press|title=Little Leaguers are set to play under the lights |date=August 24, 1992 |page=1C}} In 2006, the fences were moved back {{convert|20|ft|abbr=on}} to {{convert|225|ft|1|abbr=on}} to all fields. This was done because [[home run]]s were becoming too common. Other renovations included the extension of the stadium roofs to the end of the [[grandstand]]s, and some [[bleacher]]s replaced with individual seats with backs, increasing seating of that type from approximately 600 to 1500. On August 19, {{llwsy|2011}}, Lamade Stadium set an attendance record for the game between [[La Grange, Kentucky]], and [[Clinton County, Pennsylvania]], with 41,848 people in the stands and on the hill.{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/23024443/central_pa_team_shut_down_by_kentucky/ |title=Central Pa. team shut down by Kentucky |agency=[[Associated Press|AP]] |newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]] |page=E05 |date=August 20, 2011 |accessdate=August 21, 2018 |via=newspapers.com}} It was later broken on August 29, {{llwsy|2015}}, when [[Lewisberry, Pennsylvania]], defeated [[Pearland, Texas]], with 45,716 in attendance.{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/23024631/pa_team_tops_texas_will_face_japan_in/ |title=Pa. team tops Texas, will face Japan in title game |agency=[[Associated Press|AP]] |newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]] |page=D03 |date=August 30, 2015 |accessdate=August 21, 2018 |via=newspapers.com}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Little League World Series|Howard J. Lamade Stadium}} *[http://www.frontiernet.net/~rochballparks3/littleleague/littleleague.htm Photographs of the Little League stadium complex in South Williamsport, PA - ''Rochester Area Ballparks''] *{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lUkpyOiju9c |title=South Williamsport, PA - Howard J. Lamade Stadium |publisher=Amazing Stadiumflights |date=2016 |accessdate=August 21, 2018 |via=[[YouTube]]}} {{Little League World Series}} {{coord|41.23|-76.98|display=title|type:event}} [[Category:Baseball venues in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Little League World Series]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Lycoming County, Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Lycoming County, Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1959]] [[Category:1959 establishments in Pennsylvania]]

{{ Infobox stadium | name = Høddvoll Stadion | nickname = | image = | fullname = | former_names = | location = [[Ulsteinvik]], [[Ulstein]], [[Norway]] | coordinates = {{coord|62.340299|5.876858|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = 1920 | built = | opened = 1921 | renovated = 1963, 1992, 1995, 1999, 2014 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[IL Hødd]] | operator = | surface = Natural grass | scoreboard = | estimated_cost = | suites = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 4,433 | record_attendance = 12,300 | executive_suites = | dimensions = {{convert|105|x|67.5|m|abbr=on|0}} | acreage = | tenants = [[IL Hødd]] (football) }}
'''Høddvoll Stadion''' is a multi-sports [[stadium]] in [[Ulsteinvik]] in [[Ullstein, Norway|Ullstein]], [[Norway]]. Home of [[Adeccoligaen|First Division]] side [[IL Hødd]], it is primary used for football, but also features an [[all-weather running track]]. The sports complex consists of the main stadium, surrounded by an [[all-weather running track]], a natural grass training pitch and an artificial turf pitch, as well as an indoor hall. Høddvoll has a capacity for 4,433 spectators, of which 2,600 have been seated.
Hødd was established in 1919 and completed the construction of Høddvoll in 1921. The original field had gravel and was located at the site of current training pitch. It went through a series of upgrades, becoming a grass field in 1989. The main stadium at Høddvoll opened in 1963, and was followed by five season in the [[Norwegian Premier League|top football league]] the following decade, resulting in various upgrades. The record attendance is about 12,300, from a [[1981 Norwegian Football Cup|1981 Cup]] match when Hødd played [[Vålerenga Fotball|Vålerenga]]. The venue saw several upgrades during the 1999, and Hødd play top-league games in [[1995 Norwegian Premier League|1995]]. Hødd played a single [[UEFA Europa League]] qualifier at Høddvoll in [[2013–14 UEFA Europa League|2013]].
An all-new stadium on the original site is under construction and scheduled for competition in 2014. It will have capacity for 3,825, all except 1,000 seated. It will be built in conjunction with '''Ulsteinhallen''' and indoor [[athletics (sport)|athletics]], [[team handball|handball]] and [[gymnastics]] hall.
==History== Hødd was established on 1 August 1919 and the club's first task was to find a suitable location to play football games.<ref name=f115>Flatin: 115</ref> As a temporary arrangement, a football field was rented for the inaugural season for NOK 400.<ref>Flatin: 14</ref> The first location which was considered was to purchase land at Holsekerdalen, but a clause in the contract resulted in 15 of 17 members voted against the purchase at a member meeting on 25 September. Instead the club landed on Høddvoll, which was partitioned out of the farm Støylane and approved by the members on 13 February 1920. The main advantage of Høddvoll over Holsekerdalen was that the former allowed for a future expansion of the facilities. The club borrowed 3,000 [[Norwegian krone]] (NOK), which was guaranteed by all adult members and some supporters. Construction stated the same year and by March 1921 NOK 8,800 had been invested in the venue. Financing was aided by a grant of NOK 2,000 from the [[Football Association of Norway]] (NFF). The venue opened that year, initially with a gravel pitch.<ref name=f115 />
IL Hødd started with athletics in 1925, which were also based at Høddvoll.<ref>Flatin: 19</ref> The first club house opened in 1932, consisting of a shed measuring {{convert|4|by|5|m|sp=us}}. The building tipped over in a storm and the locker rooms were thereafter moved to a nearby farmhouse at Støylane.<ref name=f113>Flatin: 113</ref> The first upgrade to the pitch was carried out in 1936, in which it was expanded to {{convert|92|by|50|m|sp=us}}. The upgrades cost NOK 1,500, of which the state paid NOK 800. Another new gravel surface was laid in 1939. A further expansion took place at the end of the [[Second World War]]. When completed in 1947, the field measured {{convert|92|by|58|m|sp=us}}. However, the NOK 22,000 investment was a heavy burden on the club's finances.<ref name=f115 /> The third club house opened in 1948, costing NOK 3,000. It featured separate locker rooms for each team, in addition to a common shower room.<ref name=f113 />
Plans for a new stadium at Høddvoll were first articulated in 1951, resulting in a visit from NFF the following year to investigate the possibilities. The motion was passed by the club's annual meeting the same year and was included near the schools in the municipal zoning plan which was being revised.<ref name=f115 /> Hødd applied for a municipal grant in 1954. This resulted in a political disagreement as to the location of the new venue. The majority in the municipal council wanted the new stadium to be located at Høddvoll, while the minority called for it to be located next to the schools. This would have given a more central placement in town, but the majority was concerned that this would not give sufficient space for future school expansions, as well as giving higher construction costs. The municipality gave a grant of NOK 10,000 towards land purchases, and Hødd paid NOK 26,321 for the necessary land.<ref name=f117>Flatin: 117</ref>
Construction commenced in 1957,<ref name=f118>Flatin: 118</ref> but there was very little progress in the work until 1961. The main reasons were the lack of funds and that the contractor went bankrupt. In 1961 there was a boost in the construction, with significant part of the work carried out by volunteers. The pitch was sown by hand in May 1962, but the wet summer caused the grass to not grow properly, and it was never suitable for the season. The pitch was re-sown in the spring of 1963, allowing the new stadium to open on 30 June 1963.<ref>Flatin: 119</ref> Construction cost NOK 200,000,<ref>Flatin: 120</ref> which included a new grandstand.<ref name=f121>Flatin: 121</ref> The old clubhouse had become too unmodern and the players instead changed at the community center and were then bused to the stadium.<ref name=f114>Flatin: 114</ref>
Hødd was promoted to the [[1966 Norwegian First Division]], which required Høddvoll to be upgraded, mostly by addition additional rows to the grandstand.<ref name=f121 /> It also saw the construction of a new club house, which featured three locker rooms, one for each team and for the referees, and a meeting room.<ref name=f113 /> Work on a running track for the athletics group commenced in 1971. Lack of funding delayed construction of the NOK 165,000 investment to be placed on hold until 1973. The completed athletics venue was opened in 1975.<ref name=f121 /> Planning of the fifth and current club house started in the early 1980s. Financing was secured through a cooperation with location businesses, with [[Ulstein Hatlø]], [[Ulstein Propeller]], [[Sunnmørsbanken]] each buying a stake in the investment of NOK 3 million. It was further expanded in the early 1990s with a kindergarten.<ref name=f114 />
The reserve pitch, the original venue from 1921 which remained a gravel pitch, was upgraded to grass in 1989.<ref name=f121 /> It was expanded from {{convert|105|by|67|m|sp=us}} to {{convert|125|by|76|m|sp=us}}. As part of a cooperation with NFF, Hødd attempted a trial to see how extensive use the field could handle. This resulted in an extensive wear and the pitch was repeatedly closed to allow the grass to heal. Ahead of the 1992 season the stadium received a roof over the grandstand and 600 seats were installed, costing NOK 1.5 million—paid for by the club's sponsors.<ref>Flatin: 122</ref>
The athletics part of the stadium was not upgraded since 1975 and by the 1990s the section was dilapidated and plans for an all-weather running track and were discussed.<ref name=f121 /> This was installed in 1999, along with a new grass turf.<ref name=stadion>{{cite web |url=http://www.hodd.no/construction/article/1h9hcgckj9j6y1akw11bf9wyph/title/hoddvoll-stadion |title=Høddvoll stadion |date=3 July 2012 |publisher=IL Hødd |language=Norwegian |accessdate=26 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202225309/http://www.hodd.no/construction/article/1h9hcgckj9j6y1akw11bf9wyph/title/hoddvoll-stadion |archivedate=2 December 2013 |df= }}</ref> This was done simultaneously because the all-weather track required the grass pitch to be moved {{convert|9|m|sp=us}} southwards.<ref>Flatin: 129</ref> While this took place, Hødd's A-team played its First Division matches on the training field.<ref name=treningsbane>{{cite web |url=http://www.hodd.no/construction/article/2mmp2e3bn5cf1twq9piaztnbf/title/treningsbane-gras-2 |title=Treningsbane gras 2 |date=3 July 2012 |publisher=IL Hødd |language=Norwegian |accessdate=26 November 2013}}</ref> The gravel pitch north of the main stadium was converted to an artificial turf field in 2003, opening on 17 October. In addition to a multiplication of the number of hours it could be used by recreational teams and the secondary school, the field could also be used during winter.<ref name=kunstgress>{{cite web |url=http://www.hodd.no/construction/article/17teoy3tsi22q14hr41gncs8zg/title/kunstgrasbana |title=Kunstgrasbana |date=3 July 2012 |publisher=IL Hødd |language=Norwegian |accessdate=26 November 2013}}</ref> An indoor football hall, Ulsmohallen, opened in 2007.<ref name=ulsmohallen>{{cite web |url=http://www.hodd.no/construction/article/1j3l73gnky0oq1oxsnns978mwo/title/ulsmohallen |title=Ulsmohallen |date=3 July 2012 |publisher=IL Hødd |language=Norwegian |accessdate=26 November 2013}}</ref>
==Facilities== Høddvoll is a multi-sports complex located at the Støylane area of Ulsteinvik, the main village in Ulstein Norway. Høddvoll Stadion has a natural grass pitch with a playing field measuring {{convert|105|by|67.5|m|sp=us|0}}. It has a seating for 2,600 spectators and 1,733 standing places, giving a combined capacity for 4,433.<ref name=stadion /> The stadium is also equipped with an all-weather running track. It is located in the vicinity of Ulstein Upper Secondary School, which also uses the venue during daytime.<ref name=kunstgress /> There are two other pitches at the site, an artificial turf pitch north of the main stadium and a natural grass pitch to the east.<ref name=treningsbane /><ref name=kunstgress /> The latter, officially named Treningsbane gras 2, measures {{convert|125|by|76|m|sp=us}}.<ref name=treningsbane /> North of the training field is the club offices, Høddvollhuset. In addition to locker rooms and club offices, it features a café and event rooms for rental.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hodd.no/construction/article/187xw57c01uey1x5dkb0gquwdv/title/hoddvollhuset |title=Høddvollhuset |date=3 July 2012 |publisher=IL Hødd |language=Norwegian |accessdate=26 November 2013}}</ref> North of the main stadium and west of the club house is the indoor hall Ulsmohallen. It features a {{convert|60|by|45|m|sp=us|adj=on}} artificial pitch.<ref name=ulsmohallen />
==Events== Høddvoll has been the home venue of IL Hødd since 1921.<ref name=f115 /> The team has played in the [[Tippeligaen|top domestic league]] of Norway for six seasons, in [[1966 Norwegian First Division|1966]], 1969–72 and [[1995 Norwegian Premier League|1995]]. The team has played a combined 60 home games at the top level at Høddvoll, drawing a total of 196,369 spectators, or an average 3273 per match. Hødd's highest home attendance is 5,297 in their inaugural season, and the lowest during play in the top season was 2,133 in 1970.<ref>Fagerli: 350</ref> The record attendance of 12,300 dates from a [[1981 Norwegian Football Cup|1981 Cup]] match when Hødd played [[Vålerenga Fotball|Vålerenga]].<ref name=stadion />
The semi-final of the [[2012 Norwegian Football Cup]] was played at Høddvoll, drawing 6,261 spectators, where Hødd won 3–1.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fotball.no/System-pages/Kampfakta/?matchId=5665017 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130222194836/http://www.fotball.no/System-pages/Kampfakta/?matchId=5665017 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=22 February 2013 |title=Hødd – Brann torsdag 27. september 2012 kl. 16:00 |publisher=[[Football Association of Norway]] |language=Norwegian |accessdate=26 November 2013 }}</ref> After Hødd won the [[2012 Norwegian Football Cup Final|2012 Cup Final]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.tv2.no/sport/fotball/hoedd-med-cupbombe-etter-straffedrama-3932838.html |language=Norwegian |title=Hødd med cupbombe etter straffedrama |publisher=TV 2 |first=Dag Slinning |last=Aarsæther |date=25 November 2012 |accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref> the team qualified for [[2013–14 UEFA Europa League qualifying phase and play-off round|second qualification round]] of the [[2013–14 UEFA Europa League]]. A major issue was if the club would be allowed to play their games at Høddvoll, or would have to use the more modern stadia [[Color Line Stadion]] in [[Ålesund]] or [[Aker Stadion]] in [[Molde]]. [[UEFA]] gave Høddvoll a green light in June.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nrk.no/mr/det-blir-europacupspel-pa-hoddvoll-1.11063187 |title=Det blir europacupspel på Høddvoll |last=Rise |first=Hans-Olav |date=5 June 2013 |publisher=[[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation]] |language=Norwegian |accessdate=26 November 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6LQWJSIpc?url=http://www.nrk.no/mr/det-blir-europacupspel-pa-hoddvoll-1.11063187 |archivedate=26 November 2013 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Hødd won 1–0 of [[FC Aktobe|Aktobe]] in Høddvoll's only European football match, but lost 1–2 in aggregate. The match sold old, drawing 2,019 spectators.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.vikebladet.no/sport/article7951409.ece |language=Norwegian |title=Espen Standal sikra sigeren |work=[[Vikebladet Vestposten]] |first=Einar Orten |last=Trovåg |date=18 July 2013 |accessdate=26 November 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6LQWJSIpc?url=http://www.nrk.no/mr/det-blir-europacupspel-pa-hoddvoll-1.11063187 |archivedate=26 November 2013 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
==Future== Høddvoll does not meet the criteria for First Division stadia, lacking such amenities as [[under-soil heating]], [[floodlights (sport)|floodlights]] and the necessary standard for locker rooms. The club is therefore working on plans to build an all-new stadium at the site of the training pitch—the site of the first stadium from 1921. The new venue will feature a main stand on the north long side and artificial turf. The project is estimated to cost NOK 50 million.<ref name=thalberg>{{cite news |url=http://www.nrk.no/mr/gar-mot-ny-stadion-for-hodd-1.7967416 |title=Går mot ny stadion for Hødd |last=Thalberg |first=Silje |date=24 January 2012 |publisher=[[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation]] |language=Norwegian |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6LQWpb5PV?url=http://www.nrk.no/mr/gar-mot-ny-stadion-for-hodd-1.7967416 |archivedate=26 November 2013 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> The main stand will feature 1,950 seated places, the opposite, south stand will feature 875 seated places, and the eastern stand will feature standing places for 1,000 spectators, for a total of 3,825. The west end will be built as part of Høddvoll Panorama, which combines commercial estate in the ground floor and eighteen apartments in the upper two stories. The new venue is certified for Norwegian Premier League and UEFA matches. Hødd will rent the stadium from the municipality for NOK 2.5 million per year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hodd.no/news/article/118vg57ktdz5b1qa4wnbdldif0/title/nye-hoddvoll |title=Nye Høddvoll |publisher=IL Hødd |date=20 November 2013 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=26 November 2013 |archivedate=26 November 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6LQVlKxaW?url=http://www.hodd.no/news/article/118vg57ktdz5b1qa4wnbdldif0/title/nye-hoddvoll |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
The main stand will be built in conjunction with Ulsteinhallen, and will feature common locker rooms and cafeteria.<ref name=thalberg /> The indoor arena will feature a hall area for recreational athletics, handball and gymnastics, with [[Dimna IL]] as the main tenant.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.vikebladet.no/sport/article6815595.ece |title=Ulstein ror Ulsteinhallen i land |date=14 December 2012 |last=Trovåg |first=Einar Orten |work=[[Vikebladet Vestposten]] |language=Norwegian |accessdate=26 November 2013 |archivedate=26 November 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6LQWy76yx?url=http://www.vikebladet.no/sport/article6815595.ece |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Both Ulsteinhallen and the new stadium will be owned by Ulstein Eigedomsselskap KF, a [[kommunalt foretak|municipal enterprise]] owned by Ulstein Municipality. The municipality estimates that the hall will cost between one and a half and two million kroner per year to operate.<ref name=odegard>{{cite news |url=http://www.vikebladet.no/nyhende/article6770233.ece |title=I full sving med Ulsteinhallen |date=5 December 2012 |last=Ødegård |first=Joar |work=[[Vikebladet Vestposten]] |language=Norwegian |accessdate=26 November 2013 |archivedate=26 November 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6LQX0n3Cu?url=http://www.vikebladet.no/nyhende/article6770233.ece |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> [[Møre og Romsdal County Municipality]] secured 47.6 percent of the investment costs and 37.6 percent of the operating costs of the new hall, to allow it to be used by Ulstein Upper Secondary School. This will give the school access to {{convert|1000|m2|sp=us}} of new floor space and daytime access to the {{convert|6400|m2|sp=us|adj=on}} athletics hall.<ref name=fkja>{{cite news |url=http://www.vikebladet.no/nyhende/article514720.ece |title=Fylkeskommunalt ja til ny Ulsteinhall |date=2 October 2012 |work=[[Vikebladet Vestposten]] |language=Norwegian |accessdate=26 November 2013 |archivedate=26 November 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6LQX3zao0?url=http://www.vikebladet.no/nyhende/article514720.ece |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Construction commenced in December 2012, with Nord-Berg as the main contractor.<ref name=odegard /> The arena is scheduled for completion in 2014, when it will become the third-largest indoor athletics arena in Norway, costing NOK 123 million.<ref name=fkja />
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Bibliography== * {{cite book |last=Flatin |first=Arne |title=Heia Hødd |year=1994 |publisher=IL |location=Ulstein |language=Norwegian |isbn=82-993310-0-5 |url=http://www.nb.no/nbsok/nb/3e01c3d7175dd1afcece208a5f65aca}} * {{cite book |last=Fagerli |first=Arnfinn |title=Norsk fotball-leksikon |last2=Nilsen |first2=Christian Lunde |publisher=Orion |year=1999 |isbn=82-458-0398-7 |language=Norwegian}}

'''LSU-Atletas'''
(2013–2014, 2015–present) | arena = LSU Sports hall | location = [[Kaunas]], [[Lithuania]] | colors = [[Yellow]] and [[Green|Light green]]
{{color box|#ffff00}} {{color box|#00cc00}} | president = | coach = [[Edas Nickus]] | championships = '''5''' [[List of Lithuanian basketball league champions|Lithuanian SSR Championships]]
| website = [http://www.atletas.lsu.lt/ atletas.lsu.lt] | h_body = ffff00 | h_pattern_b = _thindarkgreensides | h_shorts = ffff00 | h_pattern_s = _green stripes | a_body = 000000 | a_pattern_b = _thinwhitesides | a_shorts = 000000 | a_pattern_s = _white stripes }} '''LSU-Atletas''' ({{lang-lt|[[Lietuvos sporto universitetas]]}} + Atletas) is a professional [[basketball]] club that is based in [[Kaunas]], [[Lithuania]], the club is affiliated with the [[Lithuanian Sports University]]. Currently the team plays in the [[Regional Basketball League (Lithuania)|Regional Basketball League]], in the past Atletas participated in the [[Lietuvos krepšinio lyga|LKL]] and the [[Baltic Basketball League|Baltic League]], before dissolving in 2007 and becoming BC Aisčiai-Atletas. In 2009, the team merged with BC Kaunas Triobet and played with the names of Kaunas, Baltai and LSU-Baltai. In 2013 club was renamed again to LSU-Atletas, which was merged with the NKL champions of the same name. Atletas are multiple time LKL finalists, and were once considered to be one of the strongest teams in Lithuania. The [[NBA]] center [[Žydrūnas Ilgauskas]] represented Atletas at the very beginning of his career. Lithuanian basketball star [[Saulius Štombergas]] was also a key player of the team back then. [[Donatas Motiejūnas]] also played for Atletas (at the time called Aisčiai) during the beginning of his career. == Former logos == Image:BC Aisčiai logo.jpg|Former BC Aisčiai logo image:Kauno
