{{Infobox golf facility | name = Royal Mid-Surrey Golf Course | image = View west from Kew Gardens Pagoda - geograph.org.uk - 226877.jpg | imagesize = | caption = View across to Royal Mid-Surrey Golf Course from Kew Gardens Pagoda | pushpin_map = Greater London | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption = Royal Mid-Surrey Golf Course | coordinates = {{coord|51|28|1.45|N|0|18|25.17|W|type:landmark_region:GB-RIC|display=inline,title}} | location = [[Richmond, London]] | establishment = 1892 | type = private | owner = [[Crown Estate]] | operator = | holes = 36 | tournaments = Antlers Open (Amateur Foursomes)
Mothers and Daughters Open | website = http://www.rmsgc.co.uk | course1 = Outer course | designer1 = [[John Henry Taylor|J. H. Taylor]] | par1 = 69 | length1 = {{convert|6318|yards|m}} | rating1 = | slope1 = | record1 = | course2 = Inner course | designer2 = [[John Henry Taylor|J. H. Taylor]] | par2 = 68 | length2 = {{convert|5634|yards|m}} | rating2 = | slope2 = | record2 = }} The '''Royal Mid-Surrey Golf Club''' is a private [[Country club|golf club]] and [[golf course]] comprising two 18-hole courses located in [[Old Deer Park]] in [[Richmond, London|Richmond]], south west London. ==Location== The course lies in an arc of [[Crown Estate]] land on the east bank of the [[River Thames]] which includes [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew|Kew Gardens]] to the north and other parts of Old Deer Park to the south. The Old Deer Park sports ground, used by [[London Welsh RFC]] and other clubs, borders the east of the course.{{cite web |url=http://www.olddeerpark.co.uk/sitePages.asp?step=4&navID=8&contentID=7 |title=Welcome to Old Deer Park| publisher=Old Deer Park private members' club |accessdate=19 October 2012}} ==History== Within the boundaries of the golf course lies the Grade I listed [[Kew Observatory]], established by King [[George III of Great Britain|George III]] in 1769. To the SW of the Observatory, under the fairway of the 14th hole of the golf course, lie the foundations of the former Carthusian [[Sheen Priory]], founded by [[Henry V of England|Henry V]] in 1414.{{cite book |author= [[John Cloake|Cloake, John]] |title=Richmond's Great Monastery, The Charterhouse of Jesus of Bethlehem of Shene |publisher=[[Richmond, London#Societies|Richmond Local History Society]] |volume=6, |date=November 1990 |page=51 | isbn=978-0950819860| postscript=. (diagram).}} The course and club were established in 1892 and [[John Henry Taylor|J. H. Taylor]], one of the famous '[[Great Triumvirate (golf)|Great Triumvirate]]' of Braid, Taylor and Vardon, laid out the 36-hole [[golf course]] on the northern section of Old Deer Park Park. [[Prince George, Duke of Cambridge]] was the club's first president and the Royal connection continued when the [[Edward VIII|Prince of Wales]] became captain in 1926. Taylor remained based at the club until 1946 and, along with greenkeeper Peter Lees, developed many features to relieve the otherwise flat landscape. Taylor handed over the role of club professional to [[Henry Cotton (golfer)|Henry Cotton]] who was succeeded by his assistant, [[Max Faulkner]]. Faulkner continued until 1953. [[Jimmy Adams (golfer)|Jimmy Adams]] took over on his return from Australia and held the post until 1969 when [[David Talbot (golfer)|David Talbot]] commenced a long and distinguished run as professional lasting 47 years. Talbot was succeeded by his son, [[Philip Talbot|Philip]] in 1999.{{cite web |url=http://www.rmsgc.co.uk/club/history/ |title=History |publisher=Royal Mid-Surrey Golf Club |accessdate=19 October 2012}} In March 2001 a fire destroyed the clubhouse and, with it, a substantial collection of memorabilia, portraits, pictures and trophies.{{cite news |first=Bill |last=Meredith |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/3002977/Amateur-Golf-Treasured-memories-are-reduced-to-ashes-in-blaze.html |title=Amateur Golf: Treasured memories are reduced to ashes in blaze |newspaper=The Telegraph |date=10 Apr 2001}} The building was replaced by a larger one and was opened in November 2003 by [[Prince Andrew, Duke of York]]. ==Courses== The course is divided into two 18-hole courses, an outer and inner course named after famous members of the club. ===JH Taylor Course=== [[File:Royal Mid-Surrey golf course, Old Deer Park, Richmond - geograph.org.uk - 136247.jpg|thumb|right|Outer course from Oxenhouse Gate of Kew Gardens]] The JH Taylor course is 18-hole, {{convert|6318|yards|m}}, par 69, with the {{convert|531|yards|m}}, par 5, second hole being the longest. ===Pam Barton Course=== The Pam Barton course is 18-hole, {{convert|5634|yards|m}}, par 68 with the 7th, par 4, {{convert|459|yards|m}}, being the longest. ==Other facilities== The course also has practice facilities and a [[pro shop]]. ==See also== * [[Richmond Golf Club]] * [[Richmond Park Golf Course]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.rmsgc.co.uk|name=Official Royal Mid-Surrey Golf Club website}} [[Category:Golf clubs and courses in London]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1892]] [[Category:Parks and open spaces in the London Borough of Richmond upon Thames]] [[Category:Richmond, London]] [[Category:Sport in the London Borough of Richmond upon Thames]] [[Category:1892 establishments in England]]

page.title: South of Ireland Open Tennis Championship

revision.comment: Deleted a duplicate 'the'.
revision.text:
{{Infobox tennis tournament | name = South of Ireland Open Tennis Championship | current = | logo = | logo size = | founded = {{start date and age|df=yes|1877}} | editions = 141 (2018) | city = [[Limerick]] | country = [[Ireland]] | venue = Limerick Lawn Tennis Club | category = | surface = [[Tennis Court|Artificial Grass]], outdoors | draw = | prize money = | website = [http://www.lltc.ie/about-us/history http://www.lltc.ie/history/south of ireland championships] | completed event = | men's singles = {{flagicon|IRE}} James Halas | men's doubles = }}
The '''South of Ireland Open Tennis Championship''' originally called the '''South of Ireland Championships''' first established in 1877 and also known as the '''Limerick Cup''' is a grass court tennis tournament that features both men's and women's competitions that is currently an official tour event of [[Tennis Ireland]]. It is held at the Limerick Lawn Tennis Club in [[Limerick]], [[County Limerick]], [[Ireland]].<ref>{{cite web |title=History - Limerick Lawn Tennis Club |url=http://www.lltc.ie/about-us/history |website=www.lltc.ie |publisher=Limerick Lawn Tennis Club |accessdate=31 July 2018 |location=Limerick, Ireland |date=2013}}</ref> The championships is Worlds Second Oldest surviving tennis tournament after Wimbledon <ref>{{cite web |title=Official Bid Book for the 2018 GGX: 10th Gay Games |url=http://igrugby.org/bingham2020/example-bids/limerick-2018.pdf |website=igrugby.org |publisher=Organising Committee of Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender Sports Limerick |accessdate=1 August 2018 |page=93 |date=2018}}</ref> but the only event to have been staged continuously for the last 141 years.<ref name="Tennis Ireland">{{cite web |title=Tennis Ireland - Hartmann Optometrists 141st South of Ireland Tennis Championships 2018 - Organization |url=https://ti.tournamentsoftware.com/sport/tournament.aspx?id=5FF7EC47-B849-478C-A4FE-653FC109C738 |website=ti.tournamentsoftware.com |publisher=Tennis Ireland |accessdate=1 August 2018 |date=2018}}</ref>
==History== Limerick Lawn Tennis Club was first established in 1877 in [[Limerick]], [[County Limerick]], [[Ireland]].<ref name="auto">{{cite web |title=History - Limerick Lawn Tennis Club|url=http://www.lltc.ie/about-us/history |website=www.lltc.ie |publisher=Limerick Lawn Tennis Club |accessdate=31 July 2018 |location=Limerick, Ireland |date=2013}}</ref> The same year the club staged the first Open Championships in Ireland in August 1877 one month after the Wimbledon Championships were inaugurated, the results of that tournament were however not recorded.<ref name="auto"/> It was not until 1879 that the first [[Irish Lawn Tennis Championships]] were staged at the [[Fitzwilliam Lawn Tennis Club|Fitzwilliam Tennis Club]] in Dublin.<ref name="auto"/>
In 1878 the first ''South of Ireland Championships'' also known as the ''Limerick Cup'' were founded <ref name="Nieuwland 2017">{{cite web |last1=Nieuwland |first1=Alex |title=Tournament – South of Ireland Championships - Limerick Cup |url=http://www.tennisarchives.com/tournament/?t=574&n=South%20of%20Ireland%20Championships |website=www.tennisarchives.com |publisher=Idzznew BV |accessdate=31 July 2018 |location=Harlingen, Netherlands |date=2017}}</ref> the men's event was won by Veere St Leger Goold.<ref name="Nieuwland 2017"/><ref name="auto"/> The event featured both men's and women's singles and doubles competitions and was the first notable tournament in [[Great Britain]] and [[Ireland]] to feature a woman's competition seven years before the [[Wimbledon Championships]] followed suit.<ref name="auto"/> In 1881 the reigning [[1884 Wimbledon Championships – Gentlemen's Singles|Wimbledon Champion]] [[William Renshaw]] and his twin brother [[Ernest Renshaw]] entered the doubles competition. <ref name="auto"/> Between 1884 and 1885 no women's event were staged.<ref name="auto"/> The 1885 and 1886 editions were won by future Wimbledon Champion [[Willoughby Hamilton]].<ref name="auto"/>
Between 1911 and 1912 the championships were won by Irishman Frank Cosbie. <ref name="Nieuwland 2017"/> With the advent of World War One the championships were still held from 1914 and 1919.<ref name="Tennis Ireland"/> Post war the championships were won again by [[Irish Lawn Tennis Championships]] finalist Frank Cosbie three times consecutively 1924 to 1926.<ref name="Nieuwland 2017"/> The tournament was still staged during World War Two from 1939 to 1945.<ref name="Tennis Ireland"/> Post war the 1953 championships were won by American player Ellis Williamson. <ref name="Nieuwland 2017"/> In 1975 the men's championships were won Michael. P. Hickey who played in 21 Davis Cup competitions as part of the Irish Team. <ref name="auto"/> British player [[Ross Matheson (tennis)|Ross Matheson]] won the event in 1991, 1994 and 1996. <ref name="auto"/> Into the 2000's Brian McCarthy was probably the most successful player he won the championships in (2010,2014) and reached the finals on four occasions (2010-11, 2013-16).
The tournament was part of the pre-open era mens tennis tour from 1878 to 1967. <ref name="Nieuwland 2017"/> Into the [[Open Era]] it did not survive as a tour tournament on the lucrative [[Grand Prix tennis circuit]] but did remain a fixture on the [[International Tennis Federation]] circuit for a short while until the mid-1990's. The tournament was downgraded again to regional status and continues to operate within the annual tennis tournament circuit of [[Tennis Ireland]]. The championships were staged in June 2018 which was the 141st edition of this tournament it was won by James Halas.<ref>{{cite web |title=Tennis Ireland - Hartmann Optometrists 141st South of Ireland Tennis Championships 2018 - General |url=https://ti.tournamentsoftware.com/sport/draw.aspx?id=5FF7EC47-B849-478C-A4FE-653FC109C738&draw=1 |website=ti.tournamentsoftware.com |publisher=Tennis Ireland |accessdate=1 August 2018 |date=2018}}</ref>
==Champions== '''Notes:''' Challenge Round: The Final round of a tournament, in which the winner of a single-elimination phase faces the previous year's champion, who plays only that one match. The challenge round was used in the early history of tennis (from 1877 through 1921) <ref>{{cite web|title=Abolition of Challenge Rounds|url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/EP19220320.2.111.2?query=Paris%20International%20Championships|website=paperspast.natlib.govt.nz|publisher=EVENING POST, VOLUME CIII, ISSUE 65, 20 MARCH 1922|accessdate=31 July 2018}}</ref> in some tournaments not all.
===Men's Singles=== Incomplete list of past winners and results included: <ref>{{cite web |last1=Nieuwland |first1=Alex |title=Tournament – South of Ireland Championships - Limerick Cup |url=http://www.tennisarchives.com/tournament/?t=574&n=South%20of%20Ireland%20Championships |website=www.tennisarchives.com |publisher=Idzznew BV |accessdate=31 July 2018 |location=Harlingen, Netherlands |date=2017}}</ref>

==Venue== The Limerick Lawn Tennis Club currently operates 12 artificial (synthetic) grass turf outdoor tennis courts and 3 squash courts.<ref>{{cite web |title=About us - Limerick Lawn Tennis Club: facilties |url=http://www.lltc.ie/about-us |website=www.lltc.ie |publisher=Limerick Lawn Tennis Club. |accessdate=1 August 2018}}</ref>

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name= Steel Aréna | image= [[File:Logo Steel Aréna.png|150px]]
[[File:Košice,_Steel_arena,_kompletní_pohled.jpg|250px|Steel Aréna]] | location= Nerudova 12
040 01 [[Košice]], [[Slovakia]] | opened = February 24, 2006 | owner = U.S. Steel Košice | tenants = [[HC Košice]] (2006–present) | seating_capacity= 8 378 |cost = [[Slovak Koruna|SKK]] {{formatprice|730000000}} ([[$]] {{formatprice|17648623.2}} in 2006 dollars,[[Tables of historical exchange rates to the United States dollar]] [[$]] {{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|17648623.2|2006}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{Inflation-fn|US}})http://www.hckosice.sk/sk/archiv/detail/kosicka-steel-arena-slavnostne-otvorena-+-fotogaleria/2739 }} '''Steel Aréna – Košický štadión L. Trojáka''' (English: ''Steel Arena – Ladislav Troják Stadium in Košice'') is the home arena of the [[ice hockey]] club [[HC Košice]]. Steel Arena opened on February 24, 2006. Its capacity is 8,343 and was named in honour of the general sponsor of the club – the [[U. S. Steel Košice]] (a member of the [[United States Steel Corporation]]) and also in honour of [[Ladislav Troják]], a [[Košice]]-born hockey player who was the first [[Slovaks|Slovak]] to win the [[Ice Hockey World Championships|World Championship]] with the [[Czechoslovakia national ice hockey team|Czechoslovakian national team]]. ==Notable events== An overview of some sport events: ;2007 *2007 The [[Martin Smith (academic)|Martin Smith]] | voices = [[Barry Davies]] | country = United Kingdom | language = English | num_series = 4 | num_episodes = 35 | runtime = 45 minutes | company = TV21 (2000–01)
[[Mentorn]] (2002–03) | distributor = [http://www.passiondistribution.com/ Passion Distribution] | network = [[BBC Two]] | picture_format = [[16:9]] | first_aired = {{start date|2000|3|20|df=y}} | last_aired = {{end date|2003|3|28|df=y}} }} '''''Techno Games''''' is a [[robot competition]] television programme that aired on [[BBC Two]] from 20 March 2000 to 28 March 2003. It is a spin-off from the hugely successful [[Robot Wars (TV series)|''Robot Wars'']]. ==Format== Schools, colleges, individuals and technology clubs competed to break world records, win medals and the grand series prize. For most events lifelike movement was required, so, for example, in the swimming event propellers were banned in favour of legs, paddles, flippers and fins. ==Events== Not all the events appeared in all of the series. *Assault Course *Cycling *Football *Gymnastics *High Jump *Long Jump *Micromouse (Wall following) *Micromouse (Maze solving) *Relay Cars *Rocket Cars and Funny Cars *Shot Putt *Solar Challenge Cars *Tug-of-War *Rocketry (Spot landing and Egg Protection) *Rope Climbing (Natural movement-arms and legs) *Rope Climbing (Artificial movement-wheels and rollers) *Sprint (Two, three, four, six and eight legged walkers) *Sumo *Swimming *Water Polo *Outdoor Events (Penalty kick, Shot Put) ==Transmissions== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! Series !! Start date !! End date !! [[Curtis Morgan]] | studio = Brain Farm Productions | released = {{Film date|2008|11|14}} | runtime = 60 minutes | country = United States, Austria | language = English }} '''''That's It, That's All''''' is a 2008 documentary film about [[snowboarding]] written by [[Brain Farm Productions]] and directed by [[Curt Morgan]].https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1346516/ It is the predecessor to ''[[The Art of Flight]]'' film, released on DVD on November 14, 2008.https://www.amazon.com/Thats-All-Travis-Rice/dp/B001LP50O4 The film presents the life of an influential snowboarder [[Travis Rice]] and his crew, while facing different challenges in the professional world of sport.http://xgames.espn.go.com/scene/gallery/8692333/50-most-influential-people-action-sports ==Cast== * [[Travis Rice]] * Jake Blauvelt * Kyle Clancy * [[Terje Håkonsen]] * [[Bryan Iguchi]] * John Jackson * [[Jeremy Jones (freerider)|Jeremy Jones]] * Danny Kass * [[Scotty Lago]] * Mark Landvik * Pat Moore * [[Nicolas Müller]] ==Locations== * Alaska, USA * British Columbia, Canada * Jackson, Wyoming, USA * Park City, Utah, USA * Tokyo, Japan * Munich, Germany * New Zealand * San Francisco, California, USA * Valdez, Alaska, USA ==Production== The film's action takes place in different places around the world such as: New Zealand, Valdez, B.C., Munich, Tokyo, Jackson Hole and Japan, including a great number of landscapes, mostly captured by a helicopter's crane camera. The making of the film took around two years and was entirely produced as high definition documentary with high values. ==Rewards== * Audience Award at [[Newport Beach Film Festival]] 2009 https://www.imdb.com/event/ev0000491/2009?ref_=ttawd_ev_1 ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|1346516}} * [http://www.thatsit-thatsall.com/ That's It, That's all] official film site * [https://www.facebook.com/pages/Thats-It-Thats-All/24870630769 That's It, That's all] Facebook page [[Category:Documentaries about sports]] [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:American films]] {{sport-documentary-film-stub}}

{{Infobox venue | name = Weidner Field | former names = Switchbacks Stadium, Sand Creek Stadium, Coleman Park | nickname = | logo_image = Weidner Field.PNG | logo_caption = | image = | caption = | fullname = | location = 6303 Barnes Road,
Colorado Springs, Colorado | coordinates = {{coord|38.895826|-104.711321|type:landmark|display=it}} | broke_ground = | built = 1985 | opened = 1985 | renovated = 2014–2015 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Ragain Sports, LLC | operator = | surface = Grass | scoreboard = | cost = $4,000,000 | architect = Populous Architects | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 5,000 | suites = 12 | record_attendance = | dimensions = Grass Pitch 120 x 76 | acreage = | tenants = [[Colorado Springs Switchbacks FC]] ([[United Soccer League|USL]]) (2015–present)
[[Colorado Springs Blizzard]] ([[Premier Development League|PDL]]) (2005–2006) }} [[File:Switchbacks Stadium.PNG|thumbnail|Switchbacks Stadium Logo (2016-17)]] '''Weidner Field''' is a 5,000 seat [[soccer-specific stadium]] built in [[Colorado Springs, Colorado]]. At an altitude of roughly 6,600 feet above sea-level,{{cite web |title=Security Service Field: Context Matters|first=Dan|last=Fox|url=http://web.minorleaguebaseball.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20060711&content_id=104479&vkey=news_t551&fext=.jsp&sid=t551|work=[[Baseball Prospectus]]|date=July 11, 2006|accessdate=February 20, 2014}} the stadium is at the highest elevation of any primary home stadium used by a professional team in the [[American Soccer Pyramid|American soccer pyramid]]. The stadium is immediately adjacent to [[Security Service Field]]. After [[Colorado Springs Switchbacks FC]] were awarded a franchise in USL Pro, now known as the [[United Soccer League]], it was announced on June 14, 2014, that the Colorado Springs City Council had approved an agreement that gave the new franchise a ten-year lease on the site.http://uslpro.uslsoccer.com/home/824281.html On March 7, 2016, Sand Creek Stadium had a name proposal approved by the City of Colorado Springs Parks Department, and the name was changed to Switchbacks Stadium. This happened to avoid further confusion with the name of the nearby [[Sand Creek High School]].{{Cite web|url=http://switchbacksfc.com/city-of-colorado-springs-parks-department-unanimously-approves-sand-creek-stadium-renaming-to-switchbacks-stadium/|title=Colorado Springs Switchbacks FC » City of Colorado Springs Parks Department Unanimously Approves Sand Creek Stadium Renaming to Switchbacks Stadium|last=Ragain|first=Nicholas|website=switchbacksfc.com|accessdate=March 7, 2016}} On February 14, 2017, Weidner Apartment Homes purchased the stadium naming rights for an undisclosed amount, and the stadium was renamed Weidner Field.{{Cite web|url=http://www.switchbacksfc.com/news_article/show/757669?referrer_id=2954845/|title=Weidner Apartment Homes Buys Switchbacks Stadium Naming Rights|last=Huber|first=Joel|website=switchbacksfc.com|accessdate=February 14, 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://switchbacksfc.com Switchbacks Website] *[https://www.weidner.com/ Weidner Apartment Homes] {{USL Venues}} [[Category:Colorado Springs Switchbacks FC]] [[Category:Sports venues in Colorado Springs, Colorado]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Colorado]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Colorado Springs, Colorado]] [[Category:1985 establishments in Colorado]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1985]] [[Category:USL Championship stadiums]] {{Colorado-stadium-stub}}

{{Infobox basketball club | color1 = white | color2 = #230D7B | name = Χ.Α.Ν.Θ.
H.A.N.TH. | nickname = | logo = Χ.Α.Ν. Thessaloniki.jpg | image_size = 150px | founded = 1921 | history = 1921 – Present | arena = New Sports Center Y.M.C.A. | capacity = 1,300 | location = [[Thessaloniki]], Greece | colors = Red, White, Blue
{{color box|red}} {{color box|white}} {{color box|#230D7B}} | owner = | president = | manager = | coach = | leagues = [[Greek C Basketball League|Greek C National League]] | current = | championships = | website = [http://ymca.gr/news-omades/athlitikes-omades/programs/intro YMCA.gr] }} {{X.A.N. Thessaloniki sections}} '''X.A.N. Thessaloniki B.C.''' is the [[basketball]] department of the Greek multi-sports club [[X.A.N. Thessaloniki]] ([[Greek Language|Greek]]: '''Χ'''ριστιανική '''Α'''δελφότητα '''Ν'''έων '''Θεσσαλονίκης''', which means ''[[YMCA|Young Men's Christian Association]] of Thessaloniki''), that was founded in 1921. It is based in [[Thessaloniki]], [[Greece]]. The abbreviation and common name of the club in Greek is Χ.Α.Ν.Θ. ('''Χ'''ριστιανική '''Α'''δελφότητα '''Ν'''έων '''Θ'''εσσαλονίκης), or H.A.N.TH. in English. Common alternate names of the club include H.A.N. Thessaloniki B.C. and C.A.N. Thessaloniki B.C., substituting the Greek letter X for the Latin letter H or C. The club is most widely known as being the YMCA Thessaloniki association's basketball club (YMCA Thessaloniki B.C.) ==History== In 1919, organized basketball began to be played by the club locally. Then in 1921, the parent athletic club [[X.A.N. Thessaloniki|Χ.Α.Ν.Θ.]] (English: YMCA) was formed, and it included a basketball section. X.A.N. Thessaloniki was one of the founding members of the first Thessaloniki regional basketball tournament (1925–26), and it finished in second place behind [[Aris B.C.|Aris]]. X.A.N. Thessaloniki has played in the top [[Greek Basket League|Greek League]] 22 times. The club also played in the [[FIBA Korać Cup]] competition in [[1973 FIBA Korać Cup|1973]],[http://www.linguasport.com/baloncesto/internacional/clubes/c3/C3_73.htm Linguasport.com Korać Cup 1973] [[1973–74 FIBA Korać Cup|1973–74]],[http://www.linguasport.com/baloncesto/internacional/clubes/c3/C3_74.htm Linguasport.com Korać Cup 1973–74] and in [[1974–75 FIBA Korać Cup|1974–75]].[http://www.linguasport.com/baloncesto/internacional/clubes/c3/C3_75.htm Linguasport.com Korać Cup 1974–75] X.A.N. also won the [[Greek B Basketball League|Greek B National League]] in 1977, and the [[Greek C Basketball League|Greek C National League]] in 1992. ==Arena and Greek basketball museum== XAN Thessaloniki's home arena is the New Sports Center Y.M.C.A., which has a [[seating capacity]] of 1,300. The club's headquarters also houses the Greek national basketball museum.[http://www.sport24.gr/Basket/epektash-gia-to-moyseio-mpasket-ths-xanth.4877455.html Επέκταση για το μουσείο μπάσκετ της ΧΑΝΘ.] ==Championships== * '''[[File:Trophy(transp).png|15px]] Thessaloniki Regional Championship''' ** '''Winners (16)''' '''(record):''' 1931, 1932, 1933, 1934, 1946, 1947, 1948, 1949, 1950, 1951, 1952, 1953, 1954, 1955, 1956, 1957 *[[Greek B Basketball League|Greek B National League]]: (1977) *[[Greek C Basketball League|Greek C National League]]: (1992) ==Notable players== {| |- style="vertical-align: top;" | * [[Image:Flag of Greece.svg|20px]] [[Michalis Giannouzakos]] * [[Image:Flag of Greece.svg|20px]] [[Sotiris Nikolaidis]] * [[Image:Flag of Greece.svg|20px]] [[Anestis Petalidis]] * [[Image:Flag of Greece.svg|20px]] [[Takis Taliadoros]] * [[Image:Flag of Greece.svg|20px]] [[Georgios Trontzos]] * [[Image:Flag of Greece.svg|20px]] [[Lakis Tsavas]] * [[Image:Flag of Greece.svg|20px]] [[Mimis Tsikinas]] * [[Image:Flag of Greece.svg|20px]] [[Nikos Zisis]] * [[Image:Flag of Greece.svg|20px]] [[Vassilis Lipiridis]] * [[Image:Flag of Greece.svg|20px]] [[Vladimir Petrović-Stergiou]] |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://ymca.gr/news-omades/athlitikes-omades/programs/intro Y.M.C.A. Official Site] {{el icon}} *[http://basketball.eurobasket.com/team/Greece/HANTH/7369?Page=0 Eurobasket.com Team page] {{C Ethniki HEBA}} {{Basketball in Greece}} [[Category:X.A.N. Thessaloniki]] [[Category:1921 establishments in Greece]] [[Category:Basketball teams in Greece]] {{Europe-basketball-team-stub}} {{Greece-sport-stub}}

revision.comment: /* Cast */
revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Youngblood | image = Youngblood (1986 film) poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Peter Markle]] | writer = Peter Markle
John Whitman | producer = Peter Markle
[[Peter Bart]]
[[Patrick Wells]] | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Rob Lowe]] * [[Cynthia Gibb]] * [[Ed Lauter]] * [[Patrick Swayze]] }} | music = [[William Orbit]] | cinematography = [[Mark Irwin]] | editing = [[Jack Hofstra]]
[[Stephen E. Rivkin]] | studio = The Guber-Peters Company
[[United Artists]] | distributor = [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer|MGM/UA Entertainment Company]] | released = {{Film date|1986|01|31}} | runtime = 110 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $8 million | gross = $15,448,384 }} '''''Youngblood''''' is a 1986 American [[drama (film and television)|drama]] [[sports film]] directed, co-produced, and co-written by [[Peter Markle]], and starring [[Rob Lowe]], [[Patrick Swayze]], [[Cynthia Gibb]] and is also [[Keanu Reeves]]' second film appearance. ==Plots== A 17-year-old farmhand from rural New York, Dean Youngblood has dreams of playing in the [[National Hockey League]]. Dean voices these dreams to his father, but receives negative feedback, and it is not until his brother, Kelly convinces their father Blane to let him try that he is granted the chance to travel to Canada to try out for the Hamilton Mustangs. At the try-outs, Youngblood demonstrates the abilities which garnered him "92 goals in the New York League" but also displays a lack of physical toughness that is so prized in Canadian junior hockey. This perceived weakness is pounced upon by a brutish player, Carl Racki, who is also trying out for the team and engages him in a fight. Youngblood quickly learns that flashiness and pure athletic ability will not be enough to be successful in this league. Despite being one-punched by Racki, Mustangs head coach Murray Chadwick, a former NHL [[National Hockey League All-Star Game|All-Star]] with the [[New York Rangers]], opts to select Youngblood for a spot on the team. He ingratiates himself to the other players through a hazing ritual in which members of the Mustangs pin Youngblood down, and Captain Derek Sutton shaves his testicles. Youngblood meets the coach's daughter Jessie after this incident, and despite his embarrassment, an early attraction is felt. After his mentor and friend on the team, Derek Sutton, is brutally injured by Racki (now with a rival team), Youngblood returns home to the farm. After a pep-talk by Kelly about the nature of never quitting, Youngblood is inspired to learn how to survive on the ice. Dean's father Blane, who initially disapproved of his son playing, especially after Kelly had been injured ending a promising career, also teaches his son some fighting tricks, stating "You can learn to punch in the barn, but you've got to learn to survive on the ice". Youngblood returns to the team, ready to confront Racki in the final game of the [[Memorial Cup]] playoffs. The game ends with a dramatic, game-winning goal by Youngblood with 3 seconds left. Youngblood demands to be left in the game as time expires to confront Racki. Youngblood emerges victorious, landing several blows to the face and body of his nemesis Racki, and is carried off the ice on the shoulders of his teammates. ==Cast== *[[Rob Lowe]] as Dean Youngblood *[[Patrick Swayze]] as Derek Sutton *[[Cynthia Gibb]] as Jessie Chadwick *[[Eric Nesterenko]] as Blane Youngblood. A 20 year NHL veteran, Nesterenko was also the film's hockey consultant.{{cite news|last1=Barry|first1=Sal|title=The Making of 'Youngblood: An Oral History|url=http://www.thehockeynews.com/news/article/the-making-of-youngblood-an-oral-history|accessdate=October 24, 2016|publisher=The Hockey News|date=August 7, 2016}} *[[Jim Youngs]] as Kelly Youngblood *[[Ed Lauter]] as Murray Chadwick, the Mustangs Coach *[[Keanu Reeves]] as Heaver, the Mustangs goalie. Reeves had played goalie while in [[De La Salle College (Toronto)|high school]], earning the nickname "The Wall". *[[George Finn (Canadian)|George Finn]] as Carl Racki (billed as George J. Finn). Finn was a former junior player in the Ontario Hockey League *Peter Faussett as Huey Hewitt *Simon Herring as Guard *[[Fionnula Flanagan]] as Miss McGill Many of the other team members in the film were actual junior or NCAA hockey players, including [[Steve Thomas (ice hockey)|Steve Thomas]], [[Peter Zezel]] (both of whom had lengthy NHL careers), [[Don Biggs]], and James Richmond. ==Reception== The movie gained a mediocre reception, with critics finding the plot derivative.{{cite news|author= PATRICK GOLDSTEIN |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1986-01-31/entertainment/ca-2888_1_dean-youngblood |title=Movie Reviews : A Violent 'Youngblood': . . . The Puck Stops Here - Los Angeles Times |publisher=Articles.latimes.com |date=1994-08-26 |accessdate=2012-08-24}}{{cite news|last=Maslin |first=Janet |url=http://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9A0DE0DA133DF932A05752C0A960948260 |title=Movie Review - Youngblood - THE SCREEN: ROB LOWE STARS AS 'YOUNGBLOOD' - NYTimes.com |publisher=Movies.nytimes.com |date=1986-01-31 |accessdate=2012-08-24}}{{cite news|url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19860131/REVIEWS/601310304/1023 |title=Youngblood :: rogerebert.com :: Reviews |publisher=Rogerebert.suntimes.com |date= 1986-01-31|accessdate=2012-08-24}} However, it became a popular VHS video rental and cable TV showing. ==Production== The filming of ''Youngblood'' took place in the east end of Toronto in the summer of 1984. [[Ted Reeve Arena]] was used as the setting for the interior of the Hamilton Mustangs home rink while Scarborough Gardens Arena was used for the setting of the arena's exterior; a third city arena was also used for filming.{{cite web|last1=Fleischer|first1=David|title=Where the Rob Lowe Cult Classic Youngblood Was Filmed in Toronto|url=http://torontoist.com/2017/01/where-youngblood-was-filmed-in-toronto/|website=Torontoist|publisher=St. Joseph Media|accessdate=August 25, 2017|date=January 19, 2017}} Several of the cast and crew had actual hockey experience and skills, though star Rob Lowe had to learn to skate, and both he and Patrick Swayze, a better skater, used doubles for many of their on-ice skating scenes. Director and writer Peter Markle was a former minor-pro and international player for the USA. Cinematographer [[Mark Irwin]], a Canadian, wore skates and a helmet and devised a special rig for shooting hockey scenes on the ice. The film's hockey consultant [[Eric Nesterenko]] was a two decade NHL veteran who also appeared as the father of the film's lead character. Keanu Reeves played goalie growing up and in high school. [[George Finn (Canadian)|George Finn]], who played villain Carl Racki, was a former OHL enforcer. Many of the other team members were actual NCAA or junior hockey players, some of whom went on to significant NHL careers. Lowe later said he "hated" learning how to skate. "I don't like any sport where you're already exhausted when you're done putting on the equipment. But that said, once I got the equipment on and was out on the ice, I loved that. I loved hitting people, being hit, skating. I love the exertion and competition, so that was all great. But it's a lot of work putting all of that shit on! Give me a surfboard and let me just paddle into the ocean."{{cite web|website=The AV Club|access-date=1 March 2017|title=Of all his films, Rob Lowe wants you to go back and watch Bad Influence |first=Will|last=Harris|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/all-his-films-rob-lowe-wants-you-go-back-and-watch-239875|date=8 February 2017}} ==See also== * [[List of American films of 1986]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} * {{IMDb title|id=0092272|title=Youngblood}} * {{Rotten-tomatoes|id=youngblood|title=Youngblood}} * {{Mojo title|youngblood}} {{Peter Markle}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Youngblood (1986 Film)}} [[Category:1986 films]] [[Category:1980s romantic drama films]] [[Category:1980s sports films]] [[Category:1980s teen drama films]] [[Category:1980s teen romance films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American romantic drama films]] [[Category:American sports films]] [[Category:American teen drama films]] [[Category:American teen romance films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films set in Ontario]] [[Category:Films shot in Hamilton, Ontario]] [[Category:Films shot in Minnesota]] [[Category:Films shot in Toronto]] [[Category:Ice hockey films]] [[Category:Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer films]] [[Category:Sports drama films]] [[Category:United Artists films]]
